It is hard to know who is going to provide the advice that will be so sorely needed under this new legislation. Who is going to conduct the inspections? Who is going to provide the representation?

In some ways, what are worse than that are the cuts to Worksafe Australia. Those cuts mean that things that go to the core issue of occupational health and safety in our society will be in jeopardy. There are going to be major cuts to Worksafe. To be fair to the government, it did say in advance that it would make cuts to Worksafe. I have to say it does not make me feel much better about it, but it is true. I wonder if the government is aware of statistics which indicate that non‐English speaking migrants are four times more likely to be killed in their first year in Australian workplaces than Australian‐born workers. If so, it seems to me that we should all be concerned that funding cuts to Worksafe Australia will lead to cutbacks to programs aimed at addressing that problem.

What I am concerned about—and what motivated me to make my first brave venture into the world of the Main Committee—is making the situation clear to the people of Australia. I want to make this clear to the people of Canberra and to the people who are affected by these cuts and by the parallel proposals to change the industrial relations laws of the country in ways that can only be detrimental to the interests of so many people—especially to people who are the most vulnerable. Those who are most dependent upon government support are those who are most vulnerable. Those who are most dependent upon the support of the great pillars of our industrial relations system are most vulnerable. I want to say to them that this is not the direction in which I believe Australians want their society to be taken.

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired, and I must say I am delighted that he has survived his expedition into the Main Committee.

speech.speaker: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure to join this debate, following my colleague the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan). He has made some very erudite remarks which mean I can summarise my speech to avoid repetition.
—And plagiarism, too!

—I will attempt not to plagiarise him—and I thought I might make some comments about what has taken place in the other chamber in regard to that in a minute. Supply Bill (No. 1) leads to a wide ranging discussion. I do not think I would do either myself or my party justice if I did not commence my contribution by making it clear to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to everyone on the other side of the House that, in every forum, everywhere I travel in Australia—whether it is locally or interstate or wherever—the very first point I make in my speech is to inform people about what we correctly call the Costello con.

speech.para: By that I mean the attempt to create the image that there is some kind of black hole in Labor's budget. I note with some interest that audiences are starting to understand that it is a con and, in fact, they are saying to me, `Oh well, that is what you politicians always do.' So the Prime Minister (John Howard) and his team, who have campaigned under this great aura of bringing new standards to politics, are already being seen by the general public as being just another lot of politicians distorting the budget figures in order to justify their policy positions.

That is not the reaction an incoming government, with the majority it has and the honeymoon period it would expect, would expect to be getting just two or three months down the track. It is worth making the point that failing to tell people that there are revised Treasury figures—that there are revised estimates on the growth rates in the economy—while painting this picture of Labor's black hole, leaves the government's position open for us to move in and explain just what is different.

It is quite markedly different to the situation that Labor inherited when John Howard had a letter from Treasury pointing out that there would be a $9.6 billion deficit—$23 billion in today's money. He had that letter and concealed it. It is an absolutely different situation to come into office to be confronted with revised Treasury estimates based on changes in the growth of the economy. I will not go into that in great detail now but I can assure members opposite that I do in every forum I visit. At the end of those discussions, when people come to talk to me about it they have understood well that it is a Costello con. They have understood well that the figures have been revised and we all should be moving on from that point.

Moving on to what? Moving on to a litany of broken promises. Here is stage 2 of the collapse of the Howard enigma—honest John. His government was wanted because he convinced the electors that really not much would change. Now what are they finding? Fightback 96, not even minus the GST. We now have the mooted three per cent tariff changes which effectively add a three per cent tariff excise on a whole range of imported goods. It is just another form of introducing Fightback plus its GST. We will be making that point. It does not surprise me that honourable members opposite look a little sheepish when confronted with the fact—as they will be in all their electorates—that not only have they been running the Costello con but they have been using it as a justification to break promises and introduce Fightback plus its GST. None of that was on the agenda that people were informed about.

break.para: I will now talk specifically about areas in my shadow portfolio of responsibility: energy and resources. There are key areas of doubt arising in this portfolio area just as there are in other areas that my colleagues have spoken about in their particular contributions.

One that is attracting some public interest at the moment is the diesel fuel rebate. Many times in our 13 years in office the Department of Finance trotted up with its proposals that the government either reduce or remove the diesel rebate as an attractive means of saving revenue in the budget. Every time it was put on the table we discussed it among ourselves and resolved that this particular measure was too important as an input cost in the primary sector to make any change to the cost of fuel. In other words, Labor, who these people constantly run around country Australia talking about as people who represent areas in the city, showed consistently during its 13 years a quite steadfast commitment to assisting the transfer to competitiveness in Australia's rural sector. Despite all the arguments and all the pressure, we resisted completely any moves to wind back the diesel fuel rebate.

It seems from the Prime Minister's statement to the National Farmers Federation yesterday afternoon that maybe the farmers have an assurance that it will stay in place for them. We are waiting to see whether that guarantee will be kept for fishing, for mining, for exploration and for all the non‐farm primary sector industries who, at the moment, enjoy the full diesel fuel rebate. Needless to say, this debate will continue until the Budget is brought down and all is revealed. The most interesting thing about this is why these people are left in doubt about something like this, especially when they are making investments now based on long-term judgments about their costs and their returns. Why would you leave them in doubt?

We are confronted here with the world's greatest environment package. We are going to flog off Telecom to pay for it but we are going to introduce the world's greatest environment package. At the same time we are proposing to increase woodchipping in Australia despite this national debate about conservation, the environment, the timber industry and the green movement that we have been through recently to the point where most Australians think that the balance must be just about right.

Despite that debate, what are these characters going to do? They are going to increase the volume of export woodchips just after we have been through this painful process of driving investment in value added production in Australia and of driving investment in plantation strategies in Australia. What are they going to do? They are going to give them back their export woodchip licences and go right back down the road of exporting woodchips and then importing paper products. It is about as loopy a policy proposal as one could imagine.

At a time when we are going to have this world's greatest environment package we are also going to increase uranium mining in Australia. There will be open slather for uranium mines. I know how those signals are received by young people in Australia. I know how those signals are received by people in urban and rural communities who have paid a lot of attention to this environment debate. I say to those members opposite that sending out signals like increasing uranium mining and increasing uranium exports and increasing woodchip exports is sending out the wrong signals.

They are industries which are very capital intensive. They employ very few people. As an analogy, I have a forest in the middle of my electorate. It is a forest that has been the subject of quite a bit of debate. In my forest—I call it mine—there are about 300 people employed in operating the timber mills and in managing the forest. There are 10 people employed at the woodchip export end of the industry. To reinstate those licences and to reinstate those export
woodchips in that forest probably adds, at best, three or four jobs for $X million worth of increased investment. However, the same investment made instead in expanded plantation or in expanded value adding in the timber mills in my region would create at least 30 to 50 new jobs. The proposed strategy is a dill strategy.

I have to say to those opposite that they are going to find it very difficult to portray themselves as marketing the world's best environment package while they are increasing the export of woodchips out of Australia and while they are increasing uranium mining in Australia.

A lot of these things raise also—and I hesitate to touch on this topic—the issue of propriety. It has certainly been touched on in the other place by Senator Collins in his questions. We have seen this crowd come into office. Okay, they are new, they are yet to learn about the responsibilities of being a minister of the Crown. They are yet to learn about the proprieties.

We have a situation where Senator Herron, to start with, has had to be told to stop practising his medicine because he cannot possibly be receiving an income as a minister of the Crown and be doing another job, particularly if he is getting paid Medibank payments while he is a minister of the Crown. There is a direct conflict of interest there and it is not acceptable that he does it. He has now got the message from the Prime Minister.

Senator Parer, I noticed in the
Australian
on the weekend, announced that his wife has had to sell her shares in BHP and some other companies. She was very unhappy about it too because she has had to take a loss. She did it because she is associated with him and there are possible conflicts of interest as he is the Minister for Resources and Energy. If you want the job you have to accept these disciplines.

But what do we have with the farmers? Where does the Prime Minister sit with the farmers in his cabinet? We have the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer), the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan), the Minister for Transport (Mr Sharp)—all serious, large property owners, all rural producers. What happens in the cabinet room when they consider the diesel fuel rebate? What happens when they consider the latest wool tax change? What happens when they consider things like incentives and subsidies for farmers who have been caught—things such as drought relief or periods of downturns in income when we have to change the Social Security provisions to enable farmers to earn extra income or receive assistance under government programs? What do these characters do? Do they suddenly put their hands up and say, `I have a direct interest in this. I am going to leave the cabinet room'?

From what John Howard said in the House of Representatives chamber I do not think they are worried about it. They do not perceive any conflict of interest. Well, by gee, we do. It is not appropriate for ministers of the Crown to be making decisions about matters of finance from which they are likely to be direct beneficiaries of their own decisions. And nowhere is this more evident than in the area of primary industries and resources.

We have also moved—already—into trying to slip things through. While we are trying to be the providers of the world's greatest environment package, we have suddenly found the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) slipping through, on the back of a Customs bill in the Senate, an attempt to remove Australia's government controls on minerals export licences. It sounds a bit complicated; it probably does not mean much. But the bottom line on it is that the federal parliament, through this legislation, gives the minister the power to
have the final say about whether any mineral export commodity can or cannot be exported, and under what terms.

Former Liberal Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser used those controls to stop sandmining on Fraser Island. They were the only measures that could be used—and they were there. During the last 13 years, Labor ministers regularly intervened in coal negotiations with our main international buyers to insist that Australian coal exporters received a better price than they had been able to negotiate. We have had many tales from the industry about the poor negotiating performance of the cartel that represents the owners and producers of coalmines in Australia, and several times the Australian minister has used this power to intervene and drive a better coal price for Australia.

Five minutes into the job, what has Senator Parer done? Stuck a little amendment in the back of a Customs bill, hoping no‐one would notice it and it would be slipped through the Senate, to scrap the whole thing altogether. Fortunately, a diligent opposition has managed to pick this up and, with the support of the minor parties in the Senate, we have disallowed that attempt. But why on earth would you do it? Why on earth, as resources and energy minister, would you slip in and hand away the only power the federal parliament and the federal government have to manage the export of minerals from Australia when we are such an important mineral producing country? It is a question yet to be answered. I know what happened but I cannot, for the life of me, fathom why.

We are seeing something very interesting developing, particularly in regional and rural electorates. I was just beside myself with joy—and I am sure the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) would like my use of that term; I heard him talking the other day about oral promiscuity, I think it was—

talk.start.para: —I certainly was not!

—Whatever it was, I thought I would say I was beside myself with joy at the election of a former member of this place, Harry Woods, in New South Wales at the weekend. It showed us that constituents in regional and rural Australia, in particular, are focusing very strongly on the performance of their local candidates and that they are no longer going to be served the drivel that National Party members wander around serving. Now they have the responsibility of government, they are going to be bound by some of their arguments and nowhere will this show up more than in the Telecom debate. We know from our own work on this that the rural cross‐subsidy is worth at least $500 to $600 million a year.

break.para: One has only to remember the experience with the Commonwealth Bank; the moment it became partially privatised, it started to dump on its country constituents by closing branches. It also started to dump on people who had high volume, low profit accounts. No‐one in this parliament should delude themselves for one minute that a partially privatised Telecom would not behave exactly the same way. No‐one is going to bear the brunt of that policy move more than those members on the other side who now represent regional and country areas.

Guess where we will be? We will be in those electorates pointing out that no matter what drivel these people serve up at local meetings, here in the federal parliament they are voting for services to be carved up by a privatised Telecom. There is a lot of meat in this first Supply Bill. It enables us to set the scene for the debate and it will be a strong debate during the next term of this first Howard government.

talk.start.para: —I call the honourable member for Lalor.

interject.speaker: ROCHER

talk.start.para: —I move:

interject.para: That the honourable member for Moore be now heard.

speech.speaker: Filing, Paul, MP

talk.start.para: —I will not take up the time of the Committee for long. The matter that has caused me to speak on the supply bill is a matter of some urgency in the electorate. It basically revolves around the question of the Nowergup airport which has been proposed in my electorate as the second regional airport in the metropolitan area for Perth.

speech.para:
This particular proposal has elicited one of the largest turnouts at a council meeting organised by the city of Wanneroo for some years. In fact, according to the
West Australian
—one ought to acknowledge one's sources when speaking—at a meeting last night in the city of Wanneroo chambers about 1,500 people turned up to protest against the proposal for a regional airport at Nowergup. Anybody in politics knows that 1,500 is a large number of people to come out from a community and protest about any sort of proposal, let alone one that is relatively localised. It indicates the concern of residents about what is apparently, on the part of the state government, being seen as a fait accompli.
I am aware that the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) also has some important matters he wants to address in relation to the supply bill.

But I would like to make a few observations about the matter, which is of concern for a number of reasons. The first is that the Nowergup regional airport is proposed to be sited on top of the Gnangara water mound, which is an important part of the water supply sources for the Perth metropolitan area.

The other important concerns relate to the impact of an airport of such a size on the residents in the vicinity. They will be affected not only by the noise of aircraft but also by all the other aspects of the conduct of such an airport that would infringe on their rights and lifestyles.

It is also important to recognise that not very far away from the proposed site is RAAF Pearce. In the article by Carolyn Martin in the
West Australian
this morning, the commander of RAAF Pearce, Group Captain Dennis Green, was quoted as saying:
. . . none of these sites—
these are the sites that have been proposed for the second regional airport in the Perth metropolitan area—
was acceptable to the RAAF and the Department of Transport had been told this.

I cannot think of anything more irresponsible than to propose the construction of an airport that is being opposed by or protested against by the RAAF who, obviously, have substantial military aircraft movements in the vicinity. He also said:
"We have the responsibility for the busiest military airport in Australia and we have to ensure its safety."
There had to be compatibility between relatively slow civil aviation traffic and fast, highly manoeuvrable military aircraft.

It has been suspected for some time by residents in the area that the state government had already selected Nowergup as their preferred site. They talked, in the first instance, of other sites. There was talk, for instance, of sites at Neerabup, Wilbinga and Ledge Point. It appears to people who have followed this particular issue for some time that the committee had already made its mind up and it selected Nowergup without properly consulting the local population.
This was the reason for such a large and angry crowd at the city of Wanneroo chambers last night.

As a person who has campaigned for some time, supporting a group known as the Residents Against Nowergup/Neerabup Airport Proposal Group, I can well understand the frustration and anger of residents when they are faced with what appears to be an intractable state government which makes a decision and then forces that decision on local residents.

Let me just make an observation, if I may, about Gnangara water mound. As Perth's major source of vital ground water, it is essential that it should be protected from pollution. Any development that occurs within its catchment areas must be guaranteed not to pollute. Problems are already occurring at Jandakot—that is the first Perth regional airport—due to plumes traced to fuel storage. No airport or industry can guarantee that this will not occur on the Gnangara water mound with either the Nowergup or Neerabup proposals.

Other major concerns that have been voiced by local environment groups—and I am grateful to them for providing me with this material—include: destruction of native bushland, wildlife and habitats; risks of ground water pollution from above‐ground or underground storage tanks; on‐site disposal of liquid effluent, including sewerage solvents and other degreasers which would pose threats to local ground water; and underground pipe work associated with above‐ground storage. Tanks would be an added risk and any leaks would be difficult to monitor. Major roads to service the facility would need to be put in place, and general operation of aircraft would require movement of large quantities of fuel, leading to the possibility of accidental spillage.

In addition, the infrastructure would increase with use and growth of the aerodrome. For example, at Jandakot, the Federal Airports Corporation sought permission to develop and extend light industry around the airport facility. There is no guarantee that this would not occur in this particular case. I have already mentioned the noise pollution and the other safety aspects associated with a very busy regional airport operating within close proximity to important regional development in the northern suburbs of Perth.

Under normal circumstances, one might cop the usual criticism: `not in my backyard', `these people are somehow opposed to development', or `they are some sort of economic vandals opposed to reasonable development'. Let me make this observation: this development is apparently going to happen at Nowergup with little to no consultation on the part of the state Department of Transport, which has responsibility for it.

At the same time, there is a strong concern, particularly on the part of those who purchased land in the last few years, about the suggestion that they effectively bought land knowing that there was going to be such an airport within very close proximity to their residences. The residents have petitioned the Legislative Council in the Western Australian parliament. They have petitioned the city of Wanneroo; the meeting had to be abandoned last night because so many people were there. They objected to the establishment of a second general aviation airport at Nowergup and Neerabup within the city of Wanneroo because of concerns about safety and noise pollution; flight paths and circuit training allowing low flying aircraft to pass over extensive established residential areas, including schools, childminding centres, aged accommodation and community facilities; the environmental impact; and the proximity to RAAF Pearce and the difficulties that may be incurred in relation to the operation of military aircraft in adjoining air space.

break.para: One of the frequent complaints of residents in the area has been the early circulation often of military aircraft. Most recently, aircraft of the Royal Singapore Air Force were training using Pearce Air Base airspace by arrangement with the Australian government. They have a memorandum of understanding and in some instances there has been strong criticism of the arrangements. Nonetheless, there is an arrangement with RAAF Pearce, and I have had complaints from residents about low flying aircraft already. I have made representations to RAAF Pearce, whose personnel have cooperated fully and have been very quick to try and rectify any particular community complaints.

In this instance, the Minister for Transport in the Western Australian government really has to look very closely at the procedures his department used to introduce this new Nowergup B site for a second regional airport. In fact, it has been estimated that there may well be anything up to 150,000 air movements in one year, which is quite an extraordinary number—it is about half the traffic currently at Jandakot. Those who are familiar with the Perth metropolitan area would know that there are some very substantial concerns from Jandakot residents about the noise, safety and other infringements on their lifestyles that they see from the operation of the Jandakot regional airport.

In conclusion, I would like to emphasise that at any stage in residential development there must be clear consultation with the community. There must be an opportunity for the community to voice their concerns long before a proposed site for a second regional airport is selected for preference by such an instrumentality as the Department of Transport.

I cannot understand for the life of me why the local Liberal state member in the state government, who has told parliament that he was not informed of this choice, was left out in the cold, or why residents have had to take the trouble of mounting a substantial protest at the city of Wanneroo and elsewhere through petitions and the like to voice their concerns. I am with the residents. Their interests must come first and, as far as I am concerned, Nowergup or Neerabup are both inappropriate sites for a second regional airport in Perth. If they want to suggest an area, they should look outside the major metropolitan growth area and, in the first instance, they must consult with the local residents.

speech.speaker: Jones, Barry, MP

talk.start.para: —I am deeply concerned that the Howard government has adopted the very short‐sighted view of classifying research effort as an expense rather than as an investment and, if there is a commitment to reducing outlays generally, research will be at the top of the list, not at the bottom. It is not the first government to take that view, and it will not be the last, but it is damaging to the national interest and a classic illustration of false economy.

speech.para: I refer to an enormously important scientific project which Australia has dropped out of, the European Southern Observatory—ESO. I know my colleague the honourable member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) will be returning to this theme later. Australia has taken the leading role in Southern Hemisphere astronomy since 1868, first with optical and later with optical and radio instruments. Because there are more interesting phenomena in the southern heavens, and Australia has a splendid view of the celestial axis, we are well placed to make the major contribution. The UK Schmidt Telescope, the Anglo‐Australian Telescope at Siding Spring, the great radio telescopes at Parkes, Tidbinbilla and the Australia Telescope, also at Siding Spring, have made tremendous international contributions.

But the European Space Observatory is a unique opportunity for us. Eight European nations are in the ESO project: Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Switzerland
and Sweden. They are proposing to build what will be the most powerful optical telescope array in the world at Cerro Paranal, a mountain in the Atacama desert in northern Chile. Why the Atacama desert, I hear the honourable members for Adelaide (Ms Worth) and Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) cry. The reasons are simple: because of its extraordinary dryness and elevation, there is no pollution, almost no water vapour and very rare clouding and so there is a very high proportion of clear nights. Atacama is regarded as the best place in the world for observation.

Uniquely of nations in the Southern Hemisphere, Australia has been invited to be a participant. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) wrote a very disturbing, dear John letter, dated 23 May 1996—in this case, a dear Ricardo letter—to Professor Ricardo Giacconi, the Director-General, the European Southern Observatory. He said that, while he would not want to rule out the possibility of Australia seeking membership at some time in the future were it to be offered, we are not able to continue with any negotiations. I make some reference about the costs involved because I think we have to put it in context. The cost suggested is of the order of $28 million. The notes read:
This consists of an up‐front contribution of $13 million determined as a GDP‐based share of the VLT's existing capitalisation—
Incidentally, I read this from some notes thoughtfully provided by the Mount Stromlo and Siding Spring observatories. I want to get the details absolutely right.
together with an annual capital subscription towards VLT—
that is, very large telescope—

construction of $3 Million per year in each of the 5 years up to the years 2000‐01. In addition there is an operational subscription of $3 Million per year to be funded through the annual contributions of $1.2 Million from the Australian Astronomy Consortium, $0.6 Million in ARC infrastructure grants, $0.4 Million through DIST and an offset of $0.8 Million against use by ESO members of the Australia Telescope National Facility.
I explain that the other $3 million there is already committed, assuming that we join ESO. The sum in new money required over a five‐year period would be a grand total of $28 million.

Australia is in a very strong position to have full recapture of the up-front expenditure. There is an accepted precedent that some European countries have followed where, if we say, `We are going to put money into this but we want our space and astronomy qualified industries to provide the equipment,' it is not hard to imagine areas for space related and astronomy qualified industries where Australia is very well placed.

There are showcase areas of industry which Australia wants to develop in Europe and where it wants to build up linkages. Most of Australia's contribution to the project would be in the form of sophisticated state‐of‐the‐art electronics, robotics, optics, image processing and software components and instruments, the development of which will help to strengthen our competitive edge in high technology industry.

The national benefits of ESO membership are very significant. Australia has been invited to join—the first member outside Europe. The time to join is during construction, when it is low cost with more benefits. The first telescope is to be opened in 1998. The ESO has a good track record. Australia will complement it. Without question, the VLT is the most important astronomy project in the world. No single country can afford to build a telescope like this. Through ESO, the Australian share of this enormous product—this half billion dollar project—is affordable. I point, too, to the regional significance of Chile, South America and the Pacific.

break.para: To illustrate the power of the proposed new instrument, I point out that the Anglo‐Australian Telescope, our biggest optical instrument, has a mirror of four metres. The ESO will consist of four telescopes, each with a mirror of eight metres operating as a phased array. That creates a synergy, where the total surface area may have resolution capacity equal to a telescope with a mirror of perhaps 20 metres—in other words, a mirror that is considerably bigger than this vast chamber that we are talking in at the moment. The great Australia Telescope commissioned in 1988 also operates as a phased array of several instruments, but that is a radio telescope.

I also draw your attention, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the creation of a new and high‐powered lobby group—the Higher Education Alliance. It consists of distinguished representatives of the four Australian academies. The four Australian academies comprise the most distinguished Australian academics—and one or two outsiders—and were set up by royal warrant.

The representative of the Australian Academy of Science is Dr Keith Boardman, the former chief executive of CSIRO. The representative of the Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering is Dr Greg Tegart, former secretary of the Department of Science. The representative of the Australian Academy of the Humanities is Professor Tony Lowe, and of the Australian Academy of Social Sciences, Professor Paul Bourke.

Universities and the CSIRO, as I can testify from my own experience as a minister, operate with a very high level of recurrent and unavoidable expenses: salaries, superannuation contributions, vehicle costs, repairs and maintenance, standard equipment. A cut of one, two or three per cent—which, perhaps when you say it quickly, does not sound like very much—has a devastating impact on what are regarded as discretionary funds available.

It has a devastating effect on attempting anything new. It can be extraordinarily debilitating. This is a by‐product in part of seeing research organisations—and I would have to confess that the previous government was very occasionally guilty of the same view—as business corporations. People say, `If you can't get a buck, if you can't get an outside contribution from industry, maybe it is not worth doing.'

The problem is that, if organisations are totally reliant on outside funding, it means that they are going to have an extraordinarily conservative research profile. Funding will come in for areas that are known and familiar and where there is a demonstrable pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. But anything of a speculative nature, anything that leads into something that is completely new, will not attract that kind of outside development.

The newspaper reports about the setting up of the Higher Education Alliance point out that it includes the Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations, the National Tertiary Education Union, the Federation of Australian Science and Technology, the Australian University Alumni Council and the National Union of Students. I cannot remember for very many years when there has been such a degree of unity. There is genuine concern about what will happen to our universities and, in particular, fear that the cutbacks will reinforce the mediocre and the familiar and encourage a very significant brain drain, where some of our finest people will disappear overseas.
I wanted to talk about the Customs Service but I will postpone that until the Customs Bill is debated. I want to spend a few moments on the recurrent problem of violence which concerns so many of us.

In 1982, the American political philosopher, Marshall Berman, published an extraordinary book called
All That is Solid Melts Into Air
, subtitled
The Experience of Modernity
. He wrote
about the impact of growing technological power coupled with personal impoverishment and alienation, the fear of being degraded, and the loss of understanding, leading to a sense of impotent rage, a loss of control and the use of violence to express that rage.

Berman is a profound student of Fyodor Dostoyevsky's great novel,
The Brothers Karamazov
, with its uncanny insight into mass murder, serial killing and alienation. I might interpolate that it is probably some time since Dostoyevsky has been raised in a supply bill.
Berman dedicated his own book to the memory of his son, Marc, who had been murdered at the age of five. There is a terrible poignancy in the words of his preface. He wrote:

Shortly after I finished this book, my dear son Marc, five years old, was taken from me. I dedicate
All That is Solid Melts Into Air
to him. His life and death bring so many of its ideas and themes close to home: the idea that those who are most happily at home in the modern world, as he was, may be most vulnerable to the demons that haunt it; the idea that the daily routine of playgrounds and bicycles, of shopping and eating and cleaning up, of ordinary hugs and kisses, may be not only infinitely joyous and beautiful but also infinitely precarious and fragile; that it may take desperate and heroic struggles to sustain this life, and sometimes we lose. Ivan Karamazov says that, more than anything else, the death of children makes him want to give back his ticket to the universe. But he does not give it back. He keeps on fighting and loving; he keeps on keeping on.
They are Berman's words, not mine.

The Port Arthur massacre which I return to was not merely a Tasmanian tragedy; it was not even an Australian one. Its implications are universal, forcing us to confront the dark side of human nature, specifically, masculine aggression, as illustrated by some elements of the gun culture.

One of the victims, Peter Nash, a 32‐year‐old painter and decorator, came from Hoppers Crossing in the electorate of Lalor. I talked to him on polling day and he visited my electoral office less than a month before he died. He was shot dead as he shielded his wife, Carolyn, in the Broad Arrow Cafe.

In a sense, the limits of philosophical debate were set out in the 17th Century by two great English philosophers, Thomas Hobbes and John Locke. They turn on different interpretations on the nature of human beings: whether human nature is debased and needs controlling, or whether it is perfectible, needing encouragement. The party of Hobbes is essentially pessimistic, fatalistic, defensive and authoritarian, while the party of Locke is optimistic, idealistic, open and sceptical.

Our political system operates in the middle ground but there are elements of Hobbes and Locke—sometimes both—in us all. But events, such as the Port Arthur, Dunblane or Oklahoma City massacres, or suicide bombings, ethnic cleansing, or saturation bombings, challenge or shake any optimistic Lockean view about the nature of human relationships.

Our media is saturated with blood inevitably leading to the risk of desensitising citizens, especially young ones, about violence. The media have moral responsibilities about selectivity and emphasis but, essentially, they report a world that they did not create. Let me just quote myself for a few moments:
Since governments might have been expected to take the lead—
taking into account the extraordinary social and technological changes of the 1970s and thereafter—

in planning for an era of unusually rapid change, collapse of confidence in the political process—a loss of legitimacy—was the most serious issue of them all. The decades following have exacerbated the problem.

In the United States, strong, rich and well‐educated, a significant minority repudiated the open society, mainstream politics, and sceptical detachment. The collapse of confidence led to a conviction that government was the
enemy
, engaged in a conspiracy against the people. Gun ownership was equated with self defence and freedom. The liberal left had deep concerns about John Kennedy's assassination, the Vietnam War and Watergate. Parallel concerns on the right were taken up by religious fundamentalists, cults and armed militias, leading, at its most extreme, to a paranoid view that Washington had become a `Zionist Occupation Government'(ZOG) and terrorist acts such as the Oklahoma City bomb blast (April 1995). As with Hitler's Nazis, this was a classic illustration of `the revenge of the powerless'. At a time when technology provided a unique capacity to break down hierarchies and promote individual autonomy, citizens felt confused, marginalised and frustrated, and fear encouraged a desperate recourse to violence.
This collapse of confidence in government has occurred in varying degrees in the former USSR, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, Italy, Japan, Canada and some Australian states.
As a democracy—one of the great democratic success stories—Australia should be devoting time and effort to understanding the problem of violence, and masculine aggression in particular.

What happens, quite often, after an incident such as Port Arthur, is that a national consensus develops very quickly. But that national consensus, which involves haste and making a very firm decision, can ebb away. We can already see some indication—I would say at the periphery of our political process rather than at the centre—of a desire to overturn the decision. I always remember some words—they turned out to be quite prophetic words—by Barry Unsworth when he was Premier of New South Wales. In 1988, the bicentennial year, he made a very serious attempt to get the states on side and the then Prime Minister agreed but there was very strong opposition from the coalition. I remember that as he left that unsuccessful meeting of premiers he uttered some unusually prophetic words:

It will require some bloody tragedy in Tasmania to bring the nation to its senses, to make people realise the extraordinary fragility of our society, the extraordinary damage, the extraordinary power that can be done with these high powered guns.
And Barry Unsworth was absolutely correct.

talk.start.para: —John Cain said similar things.

—John Cain said similar things in Victoria. The tragedy is that it has taken a period of eight years before we have almost got to that point of consensus. My real fear—in the 58 seconds that remain—is that we will lose the will to get together. I understand that there are special problems in rural areas. I understand the problems that many farmers have. I am sure those problems can be negotiated away.

break.para: The nature of the constitution means that the state with the weakest gun control system in fact determines what happens across the nation. If somebody is able to get guns in Tasmania, it is very difficult to prevent them from crossing into the other states. So that is why we have to have the uniform standard. I urge the parliament to make sure that we apply all the pressures that we can within our own political processes.

talk.start.para: —Order! I understand that it would suit the purposes of the Main Committee for the sitting to be suspended and the chair to be resumed at 8 p.m.

para.emphasis: Sitting suspended from 6.26 p.m. to 8 p.m.

speech.speaker: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

talk.start.para:
—I want to make a contribution this evening on the Supply Bill to outline a number of problems I see in the government's program, as far as we are able to determine it. As Saul points out in his excellent commentary on modern technocracies—
The Doubter's Companion
—`A nation cannot make debts sustainable by cutting costs. Cuts may produce marginal savings, but savings are not cash flow'—a lesson the current government does not seem to have learned. It is another example of what Saul calls the alchemist's temptation.

speech.para: Mrs Thatcher spent a decade trying to slash the British national debt. She had the advantage of being able to use the North Sea income for this purpose, something the government is trying to do with Telstra—a very similar set of proposals. I remind it that the result was a damaged industrial sector, economic stagnation and endemic unemployment.

If undertaken too rapidly or extensively, the payment of debt can be a major drain on investment and growth. We see, for example, proposals to cut DIFF and EMDG, making exports more problematic than they have been in the past. An obsession with debt repayment to the exclusion of other economic and social values indicates a narrow and very managerial approach to economics and one, incidentally, bound to fail.

I would like to just briefly and perhaps with some humour draw on the same writer I mentioned earlier, Saul, and
The Doubter's Companion
. He underlines the need for a degree of realism from the government, which I think is lacking, and shows some scepticism about, for instance, Treasury forecasts and economic predictions. Saul says:

Draw up a list of the large economic problems to have struck the West over the last quarter century, determine the dominant strand of advice offered in each case by the community of economists, calculate how many times this advice was followed—and more often than not it was—finally, add up the number of times this advice solved the problem. The answer—
he says, humorously but accurately—
seems to be zero.

In recent weeks the coalition has sought to create the impression that they are faced with a substantial blow‐out in the budget deficit as a result of Labor's financial mismanagement. Indeed, it is a result of Treasury forecasts having changed.

It is a very cynical and convenient fiction which they hope will provide a blind for their intended and ideologically driven cuts to the public sector and to government programs. Many of the floated cuts bear a striking resemblance to those included in the now discredited Fightback document, which the coalition took to the 1993 election and which was, incidentally, repudiated by the Australian people.

The view expressed by three senior academic experts in this field exposes the lie of Costello's claims. They argue, tellingly, that the focus first of all is on the wrong figure, that the figure itself is not a firm figure and that budget cuts of the magnitude proposed by the government may produce the opposite effect to that intended and actually slow down the economy and increase unemployment—the Thatcher warning.

Professors Argy, Gruen and Neville ask that the public debate on the deficit be put in perspective. They point out that the consideration should include the non‐budget sector and the outcome of state government finances at the very least. Whether such expenditure is incurred for capital or recurrent expenditure is also seen as critical for any intelligent assessment of its potential impact—again something that is lacking from the government.

break.para: The professors also point out that the $8 billion `is not firm'—a polite way, in my view, of saying they are very rubbery—since it is based on a Treasury forecast assuming no policy changes and a growth rate of the economy of 3.25 per cent. This is a reduction of 0.5 per cent in each of the years 1995‐96, 1996‐97 and 1997‐98. Indeed, the figures that will come out this week may well repudiate that figure.

Such a difference and the associated changes forecast in employment growth, which they say will be slower, and inflation, which they say will be higher, account for 90 per cent of the change in budget forecasts. The Treasurer's own press release—perhaps this was a Treasury bit and not his own political spin—admits that figures are subject to substantial revision. You can bet your life on that!

Clearly, the agenda for the coalition is to encourage a public perception that they have no choice, poor souls, but to break their election promises or in some cases to cut functions and effective programs in order to fund some of those it committed to during the campaign. So out the window with what works and in with the experiments.

Estimates from the Department of Finance demonstrated that they made $6.7 billion worth of commitments during the election campaign, but there were serious shortfalls and inaccuracies in their costings making their proposed `savings' of $8.8 billion inadequate. In fact, they have a $4 billion hole in the budget all of their own making.

One of the most alarming aspects of the government's rhetoric and of its apparently intended strategy is that cuts of the magnitude proposed may exacerbate unemployment and slow growth, and a lot of people are now worried about that outcome.

The purported relationship between reductions in the government budget deficit and interest rates is speculative at best, though it is often repeated by the Treasurer, with little academic background. It is estimated by reputable commentators, as opposed to the Treasurer, to be of vanishingly small significance even if it is accepted. Indeed, the Reserve Bank governor recently repudiated any significant connection between a budget deficit reduction and interest rates but he did point to the importance of wage restraint, when the coalition has clearly abandoned a wages policy with predictable economic outcomes.

It is important to say that all these cuts translate into real effects on public sector employment, on the purchase of goods and services by government, and on the extent and quality of services provided to the community. Many of them, I might say, have irreversible long‐term effects. I do not believe any government has the right to sell off an asset the size of Telstra, for example.

It also has effects on entitlements and benefits provided to individuals, to families and to businesses. None of the cuts anticipated so far appear to offer any prospect at all for improvement in the standard of living or the quality of life for the average Australian. That is what voters at least have a right to expect. All of this needs to be viewed in the context of the Prime Minister's promise that his party would honour its promises even if the budget circumstances were found to be worse than they were publicly stated to be by the government of the day.

It is clear that senior members of the coalition and their economic advisers were aware—clearly aware—of the slowing of the economy and the possible deterioration in budget outcomes. There was a lot of speculation about it. Therefore, there can be no excuse at all for the blatant breaches of commitment that they now appear to be contemplating. There is no excuse at all. They understood the circumstances.

It is worth noting too, before I go on to a couple of areas of specific cuts, that Australia's public sector is already very lean. So when they say they are going to cut the public sector, they mean they are cutting programs, handing them back to the states with a discount.

Australia already has the second smallest public sector, and that includes all levels of government, among OECD nations. Since 1983, the population has grown by 17.4 per cent and GDP by 51 per cent. However, during that same period the number of public servants has dropped by 18 per cent, hardly fat in the system. It needs to be remembered that the effects of substantial and sudden reductions in the public sector work force will be felt, and are already being felt, not only in the ACT but also in regional Australia. The reductions imposed exceed already the promised maximum of 2,500 people and are, with the two per cent running cost reductions, already in excess of 9,000. And that is before we get to the budget.

If you look at Supply that we are talking about this evening, it is already mooted that there will be cuts to environmental programs quite apart from those which will result from the inept attempt to link the sale of a major public asset, Telstra, with decent funding for the environment and land care programs. There are going to be cuts on top of that. The minister himself, on the weekend, said that the $1 billion fund was planned to be built on existing programs. He said that that was `our ideal', that that is `what we would like'. He added that existing programs, however, are being reviewed in the way that all programs are. In other words, there are going to be cuts before they get to that point to find savings. He said that `it was to be additional money'. Notice the past tense. It is not now to be additional money.

The government, for instance, has not indicated in the lead‐up to this supply bill that it will provide for any more than the maintenance of the former government's forward estimates. That means that funding for 10 key conservation programs will actually cease on 30 June. We have not heard from the government that they propose to do anything other than cut these programs. Unless new funds are appropriated—and they have to make a decision to do it—programs to prevent industrial pollution, to combat feral animal and weed proliferation, and to protect nature reserves, to name but a few, will all be without operating funds. We have not heard a whisper from the minister. Over $40 million that goes on these programs will be lost in a full year, and that is before we get to the question of what they will do when it comes to the budget later this year.

Landcare projects, much loved by the rural community and supported by the government when in opposition, will be reduced by approximately $20 million in this year alone. Over the four years, without any new appropriations—and leaving aside the question of additional funds allegedly provided from the sale of Telstra—there will be a $200 million reduction. So before we get to this grand new fund which is supposed to provide $700 million in additional expenditure, we will be going backwards by at least $200 million. That is not to mention proposals to cut the Environmental Protection Authority and other programs within the environmental protection area.

Revised forward estimates to fund the former government's forward looking land package worth some $460.7 million and to ensure the continuation of current programs beyond the 30 June deadline are not to be funded, apparently. So there are no forward estimates. Programs that finish on 30 June will disappear. That is a loss of at least $200 million over the next four years, and yet they are telling us that they take the environment seriously as a priority.

This means that initiatives to maintain and expand landcare, to rehabilitate the Murray‐Darling Basin, to expand the national reserve system, to protect endangered species, and to
further fund programs for vegetation enhancement and improvement of water quality and river systems will simply not be funded. So do not worry about this argument about Telstra. They are going to be cutting back ahead of any proposals of that kind. As I say, that is bound to fail, given that all the parties indicated before the election and before the link with the environment program that it would not be supported.

I turn to another area for which I have responsibility in opposition, and that is women's programs. Recent reports suggest—and it has not been repudiated anywhere—that the government is proposing to reduce the funding and operations of the Office of the Status of Women by as much as 40 per cent. It is a tiny office anyway. The government has not contradicted reports that these cuts will result in the abolition of anything other than policy development roles. So all the programs will go out the window. That is a change that would, for instance, threaten the domestic violence programs.

I am stunned by the hypocrisy of this. In the light of the horrific events in Tasmania and continuing severe problems with domestic violence in Australia, the notion that anti‐violence programs should be reduced and that that is justified is grotesque. The Office of the Status of Women has been responsible, and solely responsible, for the very successful national domestic violence program, including the national and community education campaign.

The previous government first tackled this issue in a coordinated fashion following a survey of attitudes towards domestic violence and concerns about continuing evidence that violence towards women was still endemic in our society. Yet this is the program that is to be thrown out the window. In relation to the debate about violence and gun ownership, there is clear evidence that a high proportion of firearm related homicides occur within the family—indeed, by far and away the majority.

For women victims, one study of gun deaths in Brisbane found that 89 per cent were killed by family members or friends and in their own homes. Almost all the homicides were committed by a male. Australia has, to date, been in the forefront in moving to change community attitudes towards rape and violence against women through government programs and legislation designed to raise the status of women and to eliminate violence.

We played a very significant role in drafting the declaration on the elimination of violence against women which was endorsed by the UN General Assembly last year. The Commonwealth community education program, Stop Violence Against Women, has already had very significant and measurable effects on community attitudes, and yet we are told this program will be cut. This national effort will be diminished.

I am also very concerned by reports—and they have not been denied by the government—that various grants to women's organisations will also not be funded. They run out on 30 June. Nothing we have heard from the government suggests that it proposes to do anything to continue them. Indeed, women's organisations have had a great deal of difficulty getting to meet the minister now responsible for the status of women, Senator Newman. She has refused, as I understand, to meet with most of the groups. They have been told she will meet with them in a round table discussion. Their funds run out on 30 June. They do not know whether they will be funded the relatively small total of $1 million in total for the next financial year.

The grants to women's organisations include grants, for instance, to the Coalition of Australian Participating Organisations of Women, a group which did an enormous amount of work in the lead‐up to the Beijing conference, and our participation led us to be proud of Australian women. Those grants support the Catholic Women's League, the Foundation for
Australian Agricultural Women, the National Council for the Single Mother and her Child, the National Council for Women of Australia, the National Women's Justice Coalition, and the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia. Many of these organisations fund staff. They do not know at this point whether they will be able to continue their programs, let alone continue paying their staff.

As I understand it, Senator Newman has allowed these organisations to meet with some of her junior staffers, people who could not even give clear decisions on behalf of government. As recently as last night they were not able to give any news on funding until the budget but in the meantime, these organisations are running out of funds. There will be a winding down of facilities and staffing arrangements. They have been told that there might be some separation of general and core funding, but again, there are no details.

They have been given no criteria for future funding, if indeed there is to be any and when the funding plans are finalised, they do not know the nature and extent of the cuts. It might be five per cent, 10 per cent, or even 100 per cent. That is an insult to women's organisations in this country.

I want to comment briefly on a couple of changes that I have seen already in the way women are treated by this government. We have been asked to commend the government for the number of women who now represent them on the benches. I, for one, would want to do that, but I have to say that there have been some examples of government attitudes recently that give me cause for great dismay rather than joy.

For instance, today in the Senate, Senator Newman, with responsibility for the status of women in this country, when talking about the problems of the budget—some of which I have alluded to today—compared the behaviour of the previous Labor government in leaving what she said was a poor budget, to a woman who might be held accountable by her husband for a messy budget. Perhaps she was momentarily flustered but she repeated it so it cannot have been entirely ex tempore. She said that if a housewife let her household budget get into the same sort of mess as Labor allegedly had left the national budget, her husband would be entitled to send her packing.

I find that an extraordinary comment from the person who is supposed to represent the women of this community. When it was first outlined to me and I saw the early transcript, I could not believe it. I thought that it was a joke, that it actually had not happened. There must have been some mistake. This woman is supposed to understand that in 1996 Australian women do not regard themselves as chattels to be thrown out the door when they make a mistake. They do not regard themselves as victims or as second‐class citizens. What have we spent the last 20 years, 30 years, or 40 years doing if not improving the status of women in this country, insisting that we not be treated and discussed in that way? Yet here we have the minister responsible for the status of women in this country describing women in terms that clearly suggest that they are second‐class citizens, that they are the chattels of their husbands and that they can be thrown out the door if they bring in a messy household budget. I hesitate to speculate on what she might think if they did something worse than that in the eyes of the husband who is allegedly the power and authority in this area.

But one of the things that I must say about this is that it is now not unique. In the House the other day, the Leader of the House described a woman on our side—she is not in the parliament but, nonetheless, she is a woman active in politics—as a girl. She had become adolescent and juvenile, although she is well and truly into her twenties—maybe even into her
thirties. I have also understood from recent sources in government that the Prime Minister now says that we are not allowed to refer to anything other than `chairmen', that we have a new political correctness. Officers in the Status of Women and some of the Prime Minister's other departments have been told, `You are not allowed to use that phrase, even if it is your preferred mode. You have to talk about chairmen or a chairman. You cannot talk about a chairperson.'

Incidentally, I think that it is worth saying that there have been other reports of that kind from departments formerly under my control in the area of health. A senior officer, when told that senior executive women in the department did not want to participate in drinks after work on the grounds that they had family and other responsibilities, and in any case it was socially irresponsible to drink before driving, told them that they should go off and hold a craft afternoon for the members of staff in that office. The leadership from the government, starting from the minister responsible for the status of women, is clearly not there.

But the new political correctness is, clearly, that women are to be seen as second‐class citizens. Every time there is an example of this sort of behaviour and thinking, I for one will draw it to the attention of the parliament and protest vigorously. I have tonight called upon Senator Newman—and I know I am not alone in this—to apologise not just to her parliamentary colleagues but to all of the women of Australia, whether they are in marriage or not; whether they are in partnerships or not. They are not the chattels of their partners and husbands, and should not be regarded in that way.

speech.speaker: Evans, Martyn, MP

talk.start.para: —I talk to the committee this evening about a couple of major issues in my portfolio area of science and information technology. In particular, I think the most critical issue I bring before the House and to its attention is our role in relation to membership of the European Southern Observatory. This is a major scientific project. Indeed, it could be said to be one of Australia's current big science projects.

speech.para: Throughout the world countries with resources, countries in the First World—the developed world—look towards the addition to humankind's knowledge of what is in the universe and how it all began. They do this through a number of projects which are often described as `big science'. These, of course, often come with large price tags. Examples of these would be the superconducting supercollider in the United States and the fusion reactor prototypes which have been developed in the United States and Russia. Other major countries have contributed to those projects as well. They usually have very substantial price tags—hundreds of millions if not billions of dollars in most cases.

But those projects seek to resolve some of the fundamental questions of the universe: the origin of our universe in time, how the universe developed, and processes which go right to the very fundamental understanding of space and time. Those questions, of course, are not ones which contribute to our economic wellbeing in an immediate sense—and I do not begin to suggest that our membership of the European Southern Observatory would either, except in a short‐term way. But those questions do need to be addressed. They are issues which have always attracted the attention of our race. Every since people turned their eyes first to the stars, those questions of the origin of the universe and the like have intrigued us.

I will quote from the document which was submitted by the Australian astronomers, the large telescope working party of the National Committee on Astronomy. This document was prepared by a group of interested astronomers in academia who then presented it to the government when this issue was first in contention. They begin their presentation with a quotation from George Ellery Hale, who lived from 1868 to 1938. He said:

break.para: Like buried treasures the outposts of the Universe have beckoned to the adventurous from immemorial times.

And that is certainly the case. Australians have often and competently responded to that call, one which I think has always been to the forefront of those who have an adventurous spirit; an adventurous mind. Australian astronomers have certainly been in those categories. We have a long and proud record of achievement in this area. It is one which I and my colleagues would have liked to see us continue.

Unfortunately, the recent decision by the new government to discontinue negotiations for Australian membership of the European Southern Observatory has brought all of that to an end. Australia's proud record in the area of astronomy is very much threatened by this decision of the government not to proceed in relation to this very vital and important project. Australia was the first country outside of Europe to be invited to join the ESO Council. Our reputation in international circles is such that we were invited to join with other European countries in this magnificent undertaking in Chile.

The European countries—and this group, by the way, excludes the United Kingdom in this context but does include Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Sweden—have always formed a consortium to ensure that work of this nature goes ahead. It has been in operation since about 1965. The site in Chile where the new telescope array will be built has, in fact, been in active use by the European Southern Observatory countries for observations for many years.

The importance of Australia being invited to join this consortium cannot be understated. It is not only based on our achievements in the past but also based on their assessment of our potential to achieve in the future. That speaks volumes for the work of Australian astronomers and it is indeed an indictment on the short‐sighted attitudes of the new government which dictate that immediate budget concerns, which are debateable of themselves, must be put to the forefront. Australia's long‐term reputation and its whole scientific credibility throughout the world is to be threatened by those short‐term considerations. I would like to demonstrate this evening that those short‐sighted attitudes are not only a threat to our position in science but also very bad economics for this country in the longer term.

The European Southern Observatory is a vital project to astronomy. It permits us to see further back in time than ever before. Madam Deputy Speaker, as you would realise, as we turn our eyes to the heavens through more and more powerful telescopes, we are looking back in time. At the moment, we are able to see back to about half the age of the universe. By looking further and further beyond those limits, we effectively look back into space. That is not particularly relevant, although it might be interesting. The important part is that we are able to look back in time.

The light from more distant objects takes much longer to reach the earth. Therefore, in effect, we are seeing a snapshot of the universe at ages billions and billions of years ago. We can therefore follow its evolution, its progress, its development over time. Theoretically, by working back to the point of origin, we can make some very strong deductions about the origin of the universe, how it came about and what its processes of evolution are. There can be few more fundamental questions about our very existence than that.

The increasing size of telescopes brings with it increasing costs. That is why people have combined together in consortia like the ESO, the European Southern Observatory, in order to ensure that those costs are spread amongst the developed countries who can afford those
kinds of projects. Australia's unique invitation to join would have come with a price tag of approximately $30 million, but that was one which was eminently negotiable by the government. Indeed, the previous government had already commissioned a negotiating team to work with the council of the ESO to negotiate our entry fee.

Regardless of what the final figure was precisely—the $30 million is a ballpark estimate, but it would not have been much in excess of that—it would have brought with it the opportunity to take part in the construction phase of the telescope itself. Some work has already been done, but many further tenders are to be called. That phase is very technical and sophisticated work, it is very high value added work and it is work in which Australia has substantial expertise. But perhaps the world is not yet as familiar with our expertise in these areas as we would like.

Participation in a project like the ESO allows us to showcase our high technical standards in these and related electronics fields and ensures that the world is aware of the expertise and capability of Australian industry, as well as the expertise and science of Australian astronomers. By being able to negotiate in the way that the previous government had commissioned its team to do, we would probably have had a very strong chance of ensuring that much of that initial fee of approximately $30 million was returned to Australian industry through contracts and tenders on the balance of the construction work of this fine telescope, which is scheduled for completion around 1998 in Chile.

Why Chile? The site is a very obscure one, but it happens to be one of the finest sites in the world for viewing the heavens. The site is some 2,600 metres above ground. It is well inland—13 kilometres from the Pacific coast—and it offers uniquely good viewing. The air is particularly still. There is virtually no light pollution from surrounding development and astronomers are able to get perhaps their best possible glimpse of the heavens from that site.

The Southern Hemisphere has always been particularly vital to astronomy. Our nearest neighbours, the Magellanic Clouds, are visible particularly from the Southern Hemisphere. The galactic centre of our own galaxy is also principally visible from the Southern Hemisphere. It passes right overhead in the long nights of winter in the Southern Hemisphere and affords us very good viewing of the centre of our own galaxy, unlike the Northern Hemisphere, from where the galactic centre cannot be seen as well as it can from the Southern Hemisphere. That is why the European Southern Observatory was built at Chile and why it is particularly well suited to working with Australian astronomers who have always practised from the Southern Hemisphere. The combination of the two would have been a particularly powerful factor.

We have always had a very strong interest in astronomy, and I think the statistics bear that out. Australia has a very high percentage of astronomers per head of population. Indeed, we have one of the highest in the world; we rate well ahead of other comparable countries. The report,
Australian Membership of the European Southern Observatory
, to which I alluded earlier, contains statistics of the International Astronomical Union membership which show, for example, the Netherlands at 11 astronomers per million of population, Australia at 10, France at 10, the UK at nine, the USA at eight, and other countries such as Germany, Canada, Italy, Spain, Japan, China and India well below those figures.

Australia has a very strong claim to fame in this area. It has a particularly strong commitment by its own domestic astronomers. They will now be greatly disappointed by this government's failure to seize the initiative in relation to the ESO. It is not only a disappointment to our astronomers but also to those people in industry who would have been
able to participate in this project. It would have allowed them to develop further their own expertise. Not only is the scientific loss enormous but also the economic loss.

This attitude equates to the government's attitude in a number of other areas. We only need to look at the state of science in Australia a few short months after this government came to power to see just what I mean. Although the new Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) was very keen to issue press releases shortly after he took office, confirming his election commitments in relation to science, those commitments have very quickly gone the way of the commitment of Senator Hill to the European Southern Observatory.

I think that was the first election promise to be broken by the government in the science area. Senator Hill, as the previous opposition's science spokesman, had committed his party to the ESO just before the election, and it was not very long after the election that that commitment was broken. Indeed, I think that would have to rate as the first and possibly the most serious breach of faith by this government in relation to our scientific community. It is such a serious issue that it will stand as a record for the balance of this government's term.

What other areas are in doubt in science? Quite clearly the whole budget is in doubt in that regard. The CSIRO, which was promised an extra $20 million by this government when it was in opposition, is now faced with $2 million to $3 million budget cuts, and even the extra $20 million which they were promised is now in doubt. So, not only do they not receive their $20 million as promised but also they will definitely incur a $2 million budget cut, which will certainly leave the organisation seriously underfunded, and a further election promise will be broken.

Other organisations such as ANSTO—the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation—and the Institute of Marine Science also face similar cuts to those which are threatened for CSIRO. Although the government might choose to describe them as efficiency cuts, in scientific research organisations already cut to the bone and already operating on a minimum budget, you will find that this will be the end of any opportunity for these organisations to move forward in any serious way that would benefit Australia as a community.

There are also doubts about the Cooperative Research Centre fifth round: some $11 million is in doubt there. This will threaten the very basis of our important CRC program. Australia has established a substantial precedent in that area: a combination of public and private sector resources which we have not seen in this country to date. The CRC undertaking is a very important one for this country. It brings the private and public resources together and engages scientists around the country on active duty on behalf of science in this country, not only for industrial ends but also for pure scientific ends. That is at risk if the program is not continued through the fifth and subsequent rounds.

Perhaps one of the most vital matters in that area is the research and development tax concession scheme. That has been at 150 per cent of eligible expenditure for some years now and it has driven significant increases in industrial expenditure on research and development in this country. We did lag behind in the past, our effort could still be improved, but the research and development tax concession put in place by the Labor government some years ago has been a vital factor in driving increased research and development expenditure in the private sector. That expenditure will bring gains in the long term, as all of these things will. That is under threat by this government. Despite their election rhetoric to the contrary, I am confident that we will see that very valuable scheme cut.

Concerning the Australian Research Council, $130 million over three years, where is that now? The council is in doubt of its funding commitment and I am sure that its doubts are very real and proper. Concerning the Chief Scientist, Professor Pitman has been asked to stay on in an honorary capacity with only his expenses being met. I understand that no decision has yet been taken on a replacement to hold his very significant office in Australian science and which provides advice to the government.

Already the scientific community is concerned about the way in which positions that were formerly reporting to the Prime Minister have now been moved to the department, to DIST itself. Indeed, the very position of Chief Scientist is under threat in the context of this government's mania to cut the immediate budget expenditure. Those are very serious issues.

We also see the reduction of a number of other important programs which have contributed towards Australia's research and development and industrial technology base. Telecommunications and information technology are vital things for Australia's future, for our place in the Asia Pacific region. But what does this government do? It takes the first possible opportunity that it can to ensure that those funds which support those programs are also cut. The export market development grant scheme and the DIFF scheme are under severe threat already. Of course, that will undermine the work of the telecommunications industry and the information technology industry to boost Australia's exports.

We have seen our electronics industry grow in this country from very small beginnings to a major and very substantial industry. I believe that if the government continues on its present course it will seriously undermine the potential for these industries to be part of our export led push into the Asia Pacific region to ensure that we are able to balance our domestic industry with a sound export base and ensure the growth of jobs in this vital information sector.

We have had enough discussion this week in the House of Representatives about the worth of certain noted American authors and the way in which that influences the thinking of Australian parliamentarians—some more than others. Indeed, the report which was circulated originally last year by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), the noted former chairman of the Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies did indeed highlight the way in which we are moving firmly and strongly into an information age.
