I will take another opportunity to relate to the House the damage which this government has already done to the information technology industry. Quite clearly, if the government's attack on science which we have seen to date in only three short months is continued with similar vigour into the balance of its parliamentary term, I think we will see that area as well under significant threat.

The minister has recently been seeking to shore up his position with the information technology industry. He has been meeting with the council of that industry to promise support and future growth in that area. However, the government's first decision was to take one billion dollars out of the capital growth of that industry by withdrawing government purchases over the next three years. That will seriously undermine our domestic production base. It is the work of the public sector which has underpinned the growth of the electronics and information industries in the past and while we would hope that a situation will arrive in the future where those industries can be completely self‐sustaining without government contracts and purchases, the reality is that it is the public sector which has funded the growth in those industries.

Telecom was a vital part in the growth of the telecommunications industry in this country. Without its direction, without its purchasing power, without its commitment to Australian industry we would never have seen the growth in telecommunications equipment that we have.

The same is true of government purchases of IT. They are purchased in the marketplace. They are purchased by open tender, usually. The reality is that the firm base of government driving innovation and domestic production has led to the industry thriving and led to it developing a sound export base. The sudden withdrawal of those through the reduction in government expenditure by one billion dollars in three years, by the privatisation of Telecom, will threaten all that we have done in the past and the very foundation of Australian science and our technology industries will be under threat.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

talk.start.para:
—This is a wide ranging debate and I will attempt to cover a few areas of concern in my electorate. Some weeks ago, in response to a
Sydney Morning Herald
report of the formation of a coalition of the major universities in this country on funding, I put out a press release because of my concern that the strength of this group—their contacts, `the old boys network'—would ensure that they would be a very decisive player in tertiary funding, at the expense of institutions such as the University of Western Sydney.

speech.para:
However, in the interim, the picture has changed very dramatically. The actions of the federal minister are such that the group is totally united now in their common opposition to various serious cutbacks. Whether it is the students, the teachers, the academics or the chancellors—they all have very grave concerns about the situation. In a report by Mark Abernethy in the
Financial Review
, Dr Carolyn Allport, NTEU president, makes the comment that the minister had stepped into her new portfolio seemingly ignorant of the history of funding cuts already forced on universities over the past decade. A fairly monstrous cut is intended to do in one year what there have been some suggestions the previous government would do in three years. As that person makes clear, they had enough problems with the previous suggestions, let alone this one from the new minister.
I also note that Professor Schreuder from the University of Western Sydney has put out a very strong statement with regard to this matter. He says:
The University was created—
the University of Western Sydney—
specifically to serve the people of the region, and any cut to its funding will be detrimental at best and catastrophic at worst . . .
Professor Schreuder further states:

Over 65% of our 23,000 students come from Greater Western Sydney, a region traditionally under‐resourced in higher education; we have 40% of Sydney's population, but whereas the rest of Sydney can offer 32 university places for every 1,000 inhabitants, in the West we can only offer eight places.

We can see that there has been deprivation. We can see the results of the idiotic policies of the previous state Liberal government and the federal sphere when they created the University of Macquarie, distant from public transport, on the North Shore, and with no reasonable access to most of Sydney. The Labor government has moved in the other direction to ensure that the area which essentially covers 40 per cent of Sydney has a university with a number of campuses which have reasonable access.

From my point of view, my electorate is not as affected as much by this as other electorates such as Greenway, Lindsay and others further west. The rail system gives reasonable access
to Sydney University. However, there is a disproportionate number of students still going to this university and it is a matter of concern. We are looking at a situation where this university is going to suffer grave problems. There is a very big question mark over the previous government's suggestion—the very intelligent decision—to utilise the previous Rydalmere mental institution. That could be used for a fairly attractive and expansionary sector to that university. This is a matter of grave concern to the whole region. It certainly represents a very big problem for the Parramatta electorate. That university campus would have had an impact on the provision of a wide range of facilities to the general public. It would have had an impact in suburbs such as Harris Park and Granville with regard to housing and, of course, it would have been very accessible to students from there.

The second matter I want to speak about is the government's decision to essentially move away from the building better cities project. My electorate has gained, in a very real sense, through the rail link between Merrylands and Harris Park. It overcomes the ridiculous situation we have at the moment whereby hundreds and hundreds of people are racing past each other across platforms, knocking each other over to change trains at Granville. It will provide very important changes to our transportation system, giving access to people on the western line and the Liverpool line to both Liverpool and Parramatta, which are major employment centres.

The reality is that when you have access to jobs, you are more likely to get those jobs. My electorate has amongst the worst unemployment problems in this country, and certainly in metropolitan Sydney. So that program, in a very concrete sense, helped my electorate. I think we are aware that it was also instrumental in innovative projects relating to housing, the inter‐relationship of housing to public transport, the possibilities of using construction both for areas like solar energy and for exports in the housing sector. So once again, this is a change which has a very decisive impact on my electorate. I congratulate the government on the Y‐link rail link and also on the work it has done at both Blacktown and Parramatta stations—the interchange for buses at Parramatta, and I think anyone would concede, regardless of politics, the very major improvements at Blacktown.

The next matter I want to speak about is the question of the TCFU 2000 development project. That is essentially a project of the previous government in relation to outworkers. We have heard a lot of rhetoric from the other side as to their very worried feelings about female wages in this country. The other day a minister lamented the fact that female rates in this country are below male rates. She somehow forgot to mention that the differentiation between male and female rates in this country is lower than in any country in the European Union or the OECD. So in reality, there is a differential, as there historically has been, but because of the centralised wage system in this country, we have managed to ensure that despite their vulnerability, despite the fact that they are in casualised industries, predominantly in the service and unorganised sectors, despite that organisational problem, despite that reality, female wage rates in this country are closer to male rates than in any of those countries.

I am now talking about an essential activity of the previous government—the outworkers project. It was interesting to watch a television program recently which explored some of the realities of the textile industry in this country—70 per cent of employees not being in the tax system and therefore vulnerable to further exploitation because of concerns that they might be exposed, and probably initially persuaded by the employer or the contractor not to be in the tax system. The vast majority are not registered for Workcover. There was the instance of an eight‐year‐old child lamenting the fact that he was extremely tired after completing his schooling each day. In regard to one company, the rate for shirts had been decreased from
$2.20 to $2.10. There was the company called New Trends that essentially had organised that wage reduction and said basically, `Take it or leave it'. There was the instance of people working about 100 hours a week to receive $400. There was the instance, in a very real commercial sense, of Country Road, a major company in this country, getting products for $14 to $27 and selling them for $69 to $189.

That is the reality out there. The previous government chose, through a project, to try to bring these people into the system, to reassure them, to support them, to make sure that they had an opportunity to be paid award rates, to be legitimate in regard to taxation and thereby to get protection on safety and other matters.

There was an article in the magazine
Workplace
in the winter of 1995 by Michael Gleeson entitled `Slaves of fashion'. It spoke of an estimated 300,000 outworkers in this country living in `Third World conditions in Australia's First World economy'. It was stated that many worked for 24‐hour stretches to finish orders; almost all worked seven days a week for an average of $2.50 an hour. We all know that regardless of the difficulties in the previous industrial system, they are going to be much more prevalent when these protections are basically destroyed. This effort by the previous government in funding the textile union to try to do something about it has gone down the drain.

I know that some of these grants to the trade union movement are debatable. If we are honest about it in the political sense, one could allege they are granted for partisan reasons and one could allege that some of them are for contributions to the Labor Party and so on. That can often be argued, but I do not think there is any argument whatsoever about there being very serious problems in this industry and the efforts being made.

I have had correspondence from the Women's Health in Industry Association in New South Wales asking me to strongly take up this matter. There might be a belief on the other side of politics that Australia is uncompetitive, that our wage rates are too high and that we should basically deregulate and force down wages and thereby be more competitive, but what we are seeing in this industry is already a very concrete problem. The decision to cut out funding for this project means that we are seeing the reality: when this project is cut out, when assistance to the union movement is cut out, it will not be replaced by any effort by the department of labour. Essentially, we are going to see a lack of interest, a lack of aggression, a lack of activity.

We saw good reason why the Western Australian Liberal Party put the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) on probation for six months. I want to be very careful when quoting in relation to the next matter I am going to deal with because I have a substantial—

para.emphasis: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

talk.start.para: —As I was saying, I was uncertain until this week why the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) was put on a probationary period, but apparently Peter Drucker was in the wings throughout. He is relevant in so far as I have a lot of quotes tonight and I want to be very careful about the proper citation of them because there have been so many quotes on these matters.

speech.para:
I am talking about the export market development grants scheme. I was on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. The former member for Wills and I had to be dragged screaming to support the majority position that these grants
should be extended to single providers in the tourist industry because, under the previous scheme, there were obvious abuses that all parties conceded were actually limited to companies that provided accommodation, transport and outings.

The industry, science and technology committee made the unanimous recommendation that those grants should be extended, and that is what occurred unanimously through this parliament. So it is ironic that we now see this rush essentially to throw them out the door to save $750 million over the next three years because a wide variety of diverse industry representatives and a large number of commentators have said that it is all right to talk about reduction, but maybe it is worth while thinking about the impact.

para.emphasis: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

talk.start.para: —As I was saying, amongst those organisations and individuals I quote is the Australian Information Industry Association. In their bulletin of 5 May, they stated that the EMDGs are the only financial support available for most IT&T exporters. Small exporters will be particularly affected as 70 per cent of EMDGs' grants go to companies with fewer than 25 staff. The bulletin went on to say:

speech.para: . . . this is disappointing as the government made an election promise not to cut EMDG. Abolition seriously threatens the spectacular growth achieved in IT&T exports in recent years . . . we are unlikely to reach our target of $A10 billion in export reserves.

Similarly, in the
Financial Review
of 30 April, Peter Roberts commented:

Industry Minister, John Moore, says business needs to share the pain with the rest of the community and should rely less on government. This hides his responsibility to develop comprehensive industry policies to further the globalisation of the economy—
and, of course, we all know that that particular minister went on the record as saying that from a policy point of view, it is stupid, but he has got a fiscal gun at his head.

In the
Age
on 20 May, Kenneth Davison similarly commented that this was obviously a `silly expenditure cutting proposal'. It hurts, he said:
. . . mainly small companies, the sector that Mr Howard claimed in the election would be the main engine of economic growth into the new millennium.

No less a source than Allen Hanberg of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures in the
Financial Review
of 23 April made a few comments. He stated:

. . . we understand the need to review and assess these programs but it must be a genuine review and a genuine assessment . . . If it's going to be a case of here's a $20 million program, let's slash it, then we would vehemently oppose that approval.

The
Financial Review—
not Mr Hanberg—said:
Mr Moore's office could not shed any light on which programs would be trimmed or axed altogether.

So we do have a very substantial body of opinion saying that EMDG programs are worthwhile. We have the record of parliamentary committees, including that in which you serve, Mr Deputy Speaker, saying that this has been a worthwhile project. We have had a public examination that shows that $9 is gained by Australian exporters for every dollar of government expenditure—that was from a 1994 review of this scheme. Similarly, it also noted in the same investigation that 70 per cent of the people who received this grant were in small business.

break.para:
I have quoted manufacturers, employers, financial commentators and the Australian Chamber of Manufactures. I dare to quote the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union. Now they are in the same basket with similar comments. In the
Canberra Times
in an article by Mike Taylor they commented that $4.5 billion of import replacement and export expansion opportunities could go down the drain with this policy decision. They said that it could cost this country 80,000 jobs by the year 2001. They noted the possibility that there will be fewer new exporters and that existing innovators would probably not make the effort. They talked of fewer firms bothering to network and of a declining interest in new technology. And they talked, of course, of infrastructure projects not being followed through.

Employers in my electorate, which historically has included a significant manufacturing base aligned to the presence of the railway field and also newer IT&T companies, have written to me expressing grave concerns about the decision of this government to get rid of the EMDGs.

Similarly, with DIFF funding we are seeing an ill‐conceived, ill thought out decision to basically cut. From my own experience on the foreign affairs committee and from a number of investigations that we have conducted into relations with countries like Thailand and Indonesia, the reality is that Australia needs DIFF funding. Our companies need it to be competitive with European companies which, essentially, get even greater assistance. A number of parliamentary committees have decided unanimously, not on a partisan basis, that this is a worthwhile scheme and have actually suggested its extension.

We have seen examples recently, whether it is Transfield with their boat project in the Philippines or projects for the provision of solar energy, which has long‐term export potential for this country, such as a project for rural villages in the Philippines. We have seen the Chinese government come out on the record, with the Embassy of China actually issuing a public statement about their concerns that Australia would no longer be regarded as a reliable country.

What we essentially have here is a policy where the assistance to Australian companies has to meet international requirements. Australia cannot just have a funding arrangement which is regarded as financially discriminatory in relation to contracts overseas. We have a wide range of people essentially saying that it is not beneficial. Finally, we have the research and development concession coming under severe attack as well.

So, taken all round, not only do we have the obvious attack on social security in this country, but there is also the attempt to deregulate the labour market in the forlorn hope that if you reduce wages to low enough levels we might be competitive—that if we replicate the situation we already have with outworkers in the textile industry, we will be competitive. At the same time, this government is monstrously cutting a variety of areas of assistance to exporters. That decision has been widely attacked.

I saw a letter the other day from a person in a small private company who said they had been so hopeful that the Liberals would win the last election and who talked about their personal experience, their dependence upon export market development grants and their great disillusionment with what has happened. So there are a number of serious suggestions in regard to exporters in this country. They will impact on my electorate and they will impact on employment in an area which already has one of the relatively worst situations in Sydney.

speech.speaker: Brown, Bob, MP

talk.start.para:
—Our consideration of these supply bills illustrates better than most other things the vagaries of the political process. It was only 21 years ago when, later in the calendar year, the consideration of similar supply bills brought
on one of the most significant and important political crises that Australia had experienced. Arising from that there was, on 11 November that year, a change of government under fairly dramatic circumstances.

speech.para: The fact that, on this occasion, there will not be a similar occurrence says nothing about the quality of the government, or about the tactics of the opposition. It simply indicates that we live, perhaps, in more placid times. But it is important for us to realise that the supply bills that we give consideration to now are part of the necessary mechanism to ensure that the funds for government and government programs are made available. That is what we are doing at the present time. And the central reason why Deputy Speakers display the sort of tolerance that you do, Mr Deputy Speaker, to enable members to range so widely across issues is because we are dealing with funds which are necessary for the government to operate and for programs to be implemented. For that reason it is appropriate that the Speaker and his assistants such as yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker, allow those wide‐ranging considerations to occur.

I want to emphasise at the outset, though, that the process of our providing funds of this kind for the government says nothing about how secure or stable, or how long lasting, we would necessarily believe this government will be. I think it is perfectly appropriate for members of the government, and supporters of the government who sit on the government benches, to indicate their pleasure at achieving such a substantial win on the 2 March.

The coalition came in after Labor had occupied the treasury bench for 13 years. We were defeated, having exercised a majority of 11. The new government which came in on 2 March occupies the treasury bench with a majority of 40. So it is quite appropriate for you to enjoy the euphoria associated with that change. But I have heard others say that if some of the new members who have come to Canberra have been given the opportunity to either take leave or resign their job, they should take leave. If, in Canberra, they are trying to decide whether they will buy a unit or rent accommodation, they should decide to rent accommodation.

I had the opportunity earlier today to give some of the reasons why I believe that advice is appropriate. One of the reasons is that while the government has such a very substantial majority of 40, on 2 March the government won 54 votes out of every 100. The opposition won 46. The opposition won 46 per cent of the vote on 2 March and got about 32 per cent of the seats. I said earlier today that I make no complaint about that. I do not take umbrage at that; that is the way the system operates when you have a large number of marginal electorates.

Of course, that is the present government's situation—a very large number of marginal electorates. In fact, Mr Deputy Speaker, you saw the results in New South Wales. There were swings last Saturday in New South Wales in some of those electorates of between 12 and over 20 per cent.

talk.start.para: —Nearly 16 per cent.

—Nearly 16 per cent in some cases. The present opposition, the former government, only needs a swing of less than four per cent to get back into government. If, when the next election is held, in whatever context, there is a swing of five per cent, the Labor Party will be back in government with a majority of 16 seats. There has only been one occasion since the end of the Second World War when there has been a change of government in Australia where the swing against the incumbent government, or towards the opposition, has been less than four per cent, and that was in 1972. On every other occasion the swing
against the incumbent government has been in excess of four per cent. We do not need even four per cent to re‐win government.

speech.para: Those people to whom I would give that very special advice—don't resign, take leave; and don't buy a unit, rent—would include the following people. Mr Deputy Speaker, as I move around this pendulum, it could well be that I would refer to one of those very significant provincial seats in Victoria which you represent. Let me indicate which ones they are: the Northern Territory, Paterson, Canning, Lilley, the next is one I hesitate to announce—Bendigo, Bowman, Makin, La Trobe, Griffith, Lindsay, Kingston, McMillan, McEwen, Cowan, Lowe, Deakin, Chisholm, Dickson, Dunkley, Adelaide, Robertson, Capricornia, Ballarat, Swan, and Parramatta. When the four per cent comes to us, as it will, those seats will go. You know, Mr Deputy Speaker, as do some of your colleagues, that I say that with good will. But when that swing occurs, they will go, as sure as I stand here. If the swing reaches five per cent, let me add to the list: Leichhardt, Page, Bass, Oxley, Eden‐Monaro and Hughes. Very, very formidable.

How insecure must those people be in the light of the results which occurred in New South Wales last Saturday just how volatile the electorate has become, how demanding the electorate has become. It certainly is—

talk.start.para: —Especially the National Party!

—Yes, especially the National Party. I appreciate the interjection of my friend and colleague, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford). Mr Deputy Speaker, could I say that you may have cause to feel a little more secure, marginally more secure, than some of your National Party colleagues.

speech.para: Interestingly too, since the last election—and this is important when we are dealing with the question of supply of funds to maintain the programs of the government—the government has persistently referred to the size of its mandate. The government has made the claim that it has secured a mandate in the House of Representatives. I have no argument with that, of course the government did, the government has a majority of 40 seats. The government has a majority in the House of Representatives. But the Democrats in the Senate secured 1.1 million votes. In fact, there were 2½ million voters who voted for the coalition in the House of Representatives who did not vote for the coalition in the Senate. We may well ask ourselves why. The reason is apparent.

I have no argument with the suggestion that the electorate endorsed the coalition in the House of Representatives where governments are made and unmade for it to form a government. But equally I have no argument with the suggestion, particularly on the part of the Democrats, that the Australian electors collectively exercised their judgment in such a way as to constrain the government in the possible excess exercise of the power that it was given in the House of Representatives. There is no question about that.

People can complain about that. I know that some supporters of the government have referred to it as a quirk of the electoral system. Perhaps it was also a quirk of the electoral system that enabled us to win 46 per cent of the votes in the House of Representatives but only 32 per cent of the seats. But we accept the collective judgment of the Australian people.

There have been some other points that have been made as well. On the question of the $8 billion black hole which the government claims it inherited, I want to refer to some comments that were made by Bernie Fraser, the Governor of the Reserve Bank. Bernie Fraser
said on 28 March that the Treasury forecast was subject to further change and that with economic growth in 1996‐97 expected to be stronger than the earlier forecast of 3.25 per cent, the starting point deficit should be lower.

The present Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who in the early 1980s was the Treasurer in the Fraser government, is on the record as having made a similar observation, that not a great deal of confidence could be placed in those forward estimates. When in the lead‐up to the election, spokesmen for the then government made the claim that not a great deal of light could be thrown on the national government's fiscal position by referring to some of those forward estimates, the simple fact is that they were right. They were saying no more nor less than what the present Prime Minister was saying in the early 1980s. They were saying no more nor less than what Mr Bernie Fraser, the Governor of the Reserve Bank, said towards the end of March this year.

Some of those observations should be made, especially in the context of those circumstances where an intervening election campaign and a change of government have taken place. It is now apparent that in the election campaign the coalition over‐estimated the savings measures inherent in the policy that it was presenting to the electorate and underestimated the cost of its new spending commitments. In fact, it amounts to a $1.2 billion gap, as far as its savings and revenue measures are concerned. There is also an additional $3.3 billion where Treasury has indicated that insufficient information was provided for it to make any sensible assessment. The result, as we know, is that there is up to a $4 billion blow‐out in the budget deficit because of this government's dishonesty in the election campaign.

I do not make any claims that have not been made by others. I make no claims that cannot be substantiated. That happens to be the position. Why the government now should continue to run with the claims that it has been making, I do not know. I do not believe that the Australian electorate is as lacking in the capacity to make judgments about issues of that kind as the present government would believe. The government has claimed a commitment to honesty, to open government. If that is the position then why, in the light of all of those other financial and fiscal disclosures, is it that the present government will not release, and has persistently refused to release, the Department of Finance advice about the real potential costs of its election promises?

I believe the tactics that were adopted by the government in the lead‐up to the election were very astute and politically very clever. I understand that the Prime Minister said to the member for Kooyong, Mr Petro Georgiou, `Petro, will you provide me with a brief statement about what you believe our tactics should be in the context of this coming election.' He asked for a brief statement, Petro Georgiou provided him with 36 pages of detailed analysis, it was followed to a T, and it worked.

I would be more prepared to accept the claim that a mandate exists for this government to introduce its policies if I were convinced, and if I had seen evidence in the lead‐up to the election, that it had released its policies in time for the Australian electorate to absorb them, consider them, judge them and to then make a decision on the basis of them. Petro Georgiou, the member for Kooyong, advised the Prime Minister not to do that and the Prime Minister did not do that. As the election got closer, you will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, as do I and all of our colleagues, that there was literally an avalanche of policies. The Australian electorate did not have the time to make the type of considered judgment that we would normally hope a national electorate should make.

break.para: When we talk about a mandate, I think the government needs to give some consideration to the legitimacy of that claim, and not just in the Senate where it does not have a majority, where non‐government members have a majority because of decisions—collective decisions—that were made by the electorate. Because of that strategy, and I do not make a great deal of this, I do not believe that the Australian electorate really had sufficient time to make the judgment that we would have preferred it make. Really, Mr Deputy Speaker, the lie was given to that budget black hole when the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer, made this claim. Could I quote it perfectly, word for word.

talk.start.para: —Provided you can authenticate the publication.

—Of course. After our more recent experiences, Mr Deputy Speaker, I appreciate enormously your advice and your effort to keep me in safe waters. In the
Australian Financial Review
of 29 April 1996, Mr Tim Fischer is quoted as having said on the
Sunday
program—and I saw that
Sunday
program, and I think I can confirm that the words are at least pretty close—that:

break.para: Each and every cut ought to be known as the BKW cuts because it arises from the actions of Beazley, Keating and Willis—they're the guilty trio.

The attempt to blame the Labor Party backfired when Mr Fischer was then forced to concede that the plan to abolish, for example, the tariff concession system had been adopted by the coalition as a budgetary saving measure before the election.

If someone maintains a position, only one chink needs to be found to destroy that position—and there it is. The Deputy Prime Minister said that each and every cut should be known as the BKW cut because it arises from the actions of Beazley, Keating and Willis, and in the next breath he was forced to concede that at least one of those cuts was one which the coalition had announced before the election. We could compound examples of that kind over and over again.

In the few seconds remaining, I want to make the point that the types of factors that will affect the budget outcome are those discretionary adjustments to the composition of the budget, especially in the context of an intervening change of government. The structural changes that took place in the economy, especially the growth rate and its impact on income, and therefore tax revenue, and on employment, and therefore outlays, are the types of factors that are going to impact on the fiscal capacity of the government.

While some claims, Mr Deputy Speaker, have been made about the fiscal irresponsibility of the Labor government, I want to emphasise that for four years, during the 1980s, the Labor government ran a surplus for the first period of years in the history of the Federation, with a cumulative surplus of $18 billion—
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Macklin, Jenny, MP

talk.start.para: —As we consider the government's supply bills, it is appropriate to consider where the policies of this government are likely to take our country. When I talk about the policies of the government, I am not just talking about the policies that were detailed in the election campaign, but rather the real agenda and policies which are starting to emerge now that the government has finally realised its ambitions of occupying the Treasury benches.

speech.para:
As we all know, during the election campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) told Australians that he wanted them to be relaxed about their society and about themselves. He
made many reassuring promises. The most effective of these promises that calmed the fears of most voters about a coalition government involved retaining the majority of the social policies of the former Labor government.
Mr Howard particularly stressed that his government would protect the vulnerable and the needy, and he stressed this again and again to the Australian public, saying:
One group in the community that's not going to be hurt are the most vulnerable.

What do we see emerging from this government's policies? We see attempts to radically alter the nature of Australian society, something which will drastically impact on the lives of most Australians and especially on the lives of the vulnerable and the needy, as we have seen with the Housing Assistance Bill that has just gone through in the other chamber. These policies, in my view, are driven by Liberal ideology about small government.

In government, Labor was forced to cope, it is true, with a period of unprecedented change. This change was both worldwide and, I think we would now accept, irresistible. It could not be ignored or locked out by erecting tariff walls or other manifestations of a siege mentality. The Labor government had to find policies to cope with this rapidly changing world.

The fact that Labor coped with this and managed it better than most other western democracies is apparent in the nature and type of society that the coalition government has inherited. It is true, and I would certainly be the first to admit, that we do have unacceptably high unemployment rates but, fortunately, they are not as high as other Western nations. It is true that there have been other undesirable and unacceptable outcomes of the need to restructure radically our manufacturing industries.

The point I want to make tonight is that Labor at no time abandoned any part of the Australian people nor did it write them off as unfortunate but inevitable casualties of this change. Labor had a genuine commitment to the vulnerable and the needy and it kept that commitment. It introduced Medicare, strengthened family payments, and the social security safety net, strengthened commitments to award wages to protect lower income earners, acted on a commitment to reconciliation with indigenous Australians and introduced Working Nation to combat unemployment. These measures helped to insulate and protect Australian society from the worst excesses of the changes sweeping the globe and led to a comparatively good level—a very good level, in the circumstances—of social equity and cohesion.

John Howard promised to retain all of these measures in spirit, if not in their exact and precise form. But what do we see emerging? Firstly, we have the spurious promotion of the so‐called $8 billion shortfall, and the previous speaker has spoken about this. This is Treasurer Costello's attempt to con the Australian people into believing that this government has an excuse to go back on its pre‐election commitments to the Australian people. And who are the Australian people first in the firing line? Will the trust funds be adequately taxed? We have heard nothing of this. No; this government uses its desire to cut government spending—a desire for small government—as an excuse to slug the elderly, working families and the poor.

Let us look at some of the budget cuts that seem to be emerging in my shadow portfolio for the Aged, Family and Community Services. Firstly, let us look at the emerging plight of older Australians under this government. The way governments behave is critical to the dignity, living standards, health and wellbeing of older people. If government supports for them are removed or weakened, it can have a devastating effect on their lives.

break.para: Between 1991 and 2011, the population of Australians aged 65 years and over will grow at double the rate of the rest of our population. When Labor was in power, it had a commitment to increase federal funding to aged care: to improve the services offered and also to increase the capacity to cope with this increasing number of older Australians. Despite this evidence, the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) is in the process of transferring large areas of his health and community services portfolio to the states. He claims that this is in the interests of efficiency and, perhaps in his view of the world, that makes sense: cut costs by dumping the responsibility onto somebody else.

But what happens to Australian society if this trend in irresponsible non‐government catches on? What if the states decide to off‐load their `inconvenient welfare and community obligations'? What if they try to pass them onto local government, other states or perhaps onto community welfare groups and organisations?

We have seen the development of these practices in the United States and we should be able to learn from its terrible experience. A couple of weeks ago, in the
Weekend Australian
, a very significant article detailed what happens to a society when the federal government shirks its responsibilities. The article gave graphic accounts of welfare recipients being offered—and this is for real—one‐way bus tickets if they left a particular state. It detailed services to the needy being deliberately reduced to a lowest common denominator. In a truly perverted reversal of economic rationalist logic, if services were reduced to a significantly paltry level, the needy would be encouraged to go elsewhere for assistance.

Is that the basis for what we see as the federalism of this government? Perhaps a trend has already begun here. I have seen reports in the press recently of the Northern Territory's Country Liberal Party government paying for a family in receipt of welfare to fly to Melbourne to live. Of course, aged care is but one of the types of support provided, especially for older Australians, in our community. In the last 10 years there has been a massive growth in the provision of services to allow older people to retain a degree of independence by being able to stay in their own homes and be supported by the home and community care program.

When asked in the House on 7 May whether this government planned to honour its promise on funding for home and community care, the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) refused to give any commitment, even though it is clearly set out in the government's policy documents. Rather, she taunted the older members of our community, those for whom she is supposed to provide care and protection, by saying:
You are going to have to just wait.
That is what she said to them!
I hope you have booked your tickets for the night of 20 August when the budget is brought down, because all the mysteries . . . will then be revealed.

I think that is a very insensitive response. That question was asked of her as a consequence of the concerns of large numbers of organisations who represent older Australians. What are the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association, Aged Care Australia, the Melbourne City Mission and the many thousands of older Australians they represent going to think about that. We on this side of the house do expect to see some hard edge but I think that is fairly callous and insensitive. The minister and this government are condemning hundreds of thousands of vulnerable people to months of uncertainty. If the government is going to break its promises, it should come out and say so and put the community's mind at rest.

Unfortunately, the rough treatment does not end there. One of the inevitable consequences of advancing years is an increased reliance on medications and pharmaceuticals. Older Australians do not take pharmaceuticals because they want to, or because they have a choice; they take them because they need to, and because they have been advised by doctors and pharmacists to take them. Yet we read in a recent
Herald‐Sun
article that this government is proposing that pensioners and war veterans would be paying up to 60 per cent more for prescription medicines. Apparently, it is proposed that the price pensioners pay for each prescription rise from the current $2.50 to $4, and that the pharmaceutical benefit scheme safety net rise from $140.40 to over $200. Today, as we well know, the Prime Minister refused to rule out this option. He refused to allay the fears of older Australians about these massive increases in the costs of absolutely necessary pharmaceuticals.

Of course, it is the case that elderly Australians are not the only ones in the community to face the prospect of serious threats to their standard of living as a result of this government's ideologically‐driven obsession with cutting spending and shedding jobs. Public housing tenants, all of whom rely on subsidised housing as a means of staying above the poverty line, are also in danger, as we have just seen in the bill that has gone through the house. Instead of providing three years of funding to the states, public housing departments are getting one year of funding. The states are going to have to come back next year and have another go.

Questions to ministers about the motives for such moves just end up with the answer, `Oh, it is mere speculation'. But, of course, what the states know in the area of public housing, is that it is not mere speculation, they have been offered one year's funding, they have not been offered three years' worth of funding, and they know full well what this is going to mean to their public housing responsibilities. It seems that those states with conservative governments are prepared to do deals with this government against the long‐term interests of users of public housing, but we can only hope that there are some states that will hold out and get a better deal for public housing tenants.

Another area of grave concern to me is the cuts that are being proposed in the education budget. I mention this because cutting public education is also a basic tenet of conservative ideology and one that has also started to reap disastrous consequences for American society. A strong public education system provides a pathway for any member of our society to rise in economic status. It prevents people from being locked into a particular class or income group and, in my view, is a fundamental part of any democratic society. I am particularly concerned about what happens to a society when basic community services and rights such as education, public health and support for the aged are drastically reduced.

At the start of this speech I said that it was the social policies of the previous Labor governments that had made Australia a much better place to live in during the changes of the last decade or so. Now, just when we seem to be able to take part in economic growth again, this conservative government is starting to reveal its true nature. If the government proceeds with its budget cuts then we can only look to the example of the United States to see the kind of things that will be in store for our community. It is there that we see the cutting of services and the polarisation of incomes that has proceeded much further than here. There we find the economic and political gurus of the New Right that inspire this government's policies.

In the United States, polarisation of incomes has been replicated by polarisation of living areas—the wealthy in their guarded enclaves, the poor in run‐down inner city slums. In the US we see many signs of a society in partial disintegration—higher crime rates, larger prison
populations, a greater frequency of crimes of violence and a high and increasing usage of hard drugs.

There is also, and this is a very frightening thing for those of us in Australia at this time, the growth of the self-styled anti-government militias. That is another sign of the disintegration of democracy in that country that comes about because of the polarisation of income, because of the lack of basic community support. Voter turnout is at its lowest, newspaper readership is down, union membership has dramatically declined and Americans are no longer drawn to join community organisations in the way that once used to define their society.

It is this latter point, the withdrawal from society, that I find the most disturbing. There seems to be the growth of a kind of fortress suburbia with frightened, lonely people huddled in front of their television sets and keeping behind locked gates and burglar alarms. Is that the sort of society that we are going to have if we are to see the cuts that are proposed to our social services? Is that the kind of society that this government is taking us towards?

It is my fear that if the coalition fails to adhere to its pre‐election policies which, as I said before, were basically the policies of the previous Labor government, if they insist on making dramatic, ideologically motivated cuts to social services, aged care, public housing and public education, then we will see the rise of the kinds of inequalities and social breakdown that are emerging in the United States.

I strongly urge the government's budgetary strategists to reconsider their proposals at this important time in the budgetary process or else we will find that our community will face the American experience.

speech.speaker: Kerr, Duncan, MP

talk.start.para: —I think that it is important for us to focus both on the larger issues that have been referred to by the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) and the smaller issues. And both on the large and small issues we find this government failing to meet the basic principle that was outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), a commitment to care for those who are least well off in the Australian community.

speech.para: What is more, that failure to care is reflected in an insincerity which does little credit to the approach which was adopted by the then Leader of the Opposition in the run‐up to the election, when he took a position virtually holding a near mortgage on political integrity yet, in key areas, he gave what could be regarded only as false assurances of comfort to sections of the Australian community—amongst them, some of the most needy and most vulnerable—assurances which have been breached deliberately and wilfully, now that the government is in office. As the Prime Minister himself said, again in a pre‐election context, nothing so undermines confidence in the democratic system as the cynical repudiation of election commitments by an incoming administration immediately upon obtaining office.

I now have the responsibility for the opposition of representing the portfolio of immigration and in assisting the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) with respect to ethnic affairs. In that area, as in so many others, the record of the government to date has been one which could only make many of the people who relied on its undertakings prior to the election sick in the guts. Why is that? It is because in three key areas there have been what anyone would regard as a cynical repudiation of pre‐election commitments.

The first area of repudiation turns on a guarantee with respect to immigrant intake that the humanitarian and refugee program would be maintained and protected. This was an explicit commitment made both by the Prime Minister and by the then opposition spokesperson for immigration, Senator Short. The commitment was to protect the humanitarian program and
it was an express commitment not to reduce the numbers for the refugee component. But when, in a debate with the then minister for immigration with respect to the humanitarian program, Senator Bolkus asked Senator Short whether the same undertaking not to reduce in numerical terms the refugee component would also apply to the broader humanitarian component, Senator Short gave that assurance. We had both explicit and implicit undertakings that these components of the program would be protected.

The baseline program that the government had established was 13,000 immigrants for the humanitarian program and 4,000 for the refugee component of it. In the year immediately preceding our leaving government, we had actually increased the humanitarian and refugee program to 15,000 as a result of requests made to the Australian government by the United Nations High Commission for Refugees. Any responsible and reasonable citizen understanding and listening to the assurances given by the then Leader of the Opposition and his spokesman would have understood those assurances to mean that at least 13,000 humanitarian program immigrants would be maintained and that at least 4,000 refugees would be admitted to Australia.

The fact is that we understand from leaked cabinet documents that these programs will be cut. These programs will be slashed. The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) cynically put forward an argument which acknowledged that there would be a breach of these undertakings, but he then put forward ways in which these undertakings, although breached, could be presentationally massaged so that the conflict between the pre‐election commitments and post‐election behaviour was less obvious. Of course, the minister has been sent out to do a grubby little job on behalf of the coalition. It is a dirty little job which I am certain does him no credit and does his government no credit.

The obvious absurdity of the position that has been put forward—that these changes do no more than reflect what the outgoing administration itself would have done—comes from the fact that the coalition's costing showed that savings of some $60 million are intended to be made by virtue of these changes. So there is deceit and there are lies, and those least able to defend themselves, the most vulnerable in society, are the target of those measures.

Then you turn to the two‐year waiting period for new arrivals in Australia. The two‐year waiting period was asserted to be an extension of what the previous Labor government had introduced as a waiting period for a number of benefits, principally unemployment benefits for new arrivals. We introduced a six‐month period. We thought that that was an appropriate balance between the responsibility of the Australian society to provide some form of residual and common welfare system for all permanent residents of this country and also a recognition that new arrivals and those that were sponsoring them had a prime responsibility to at least meet those initial settlement costs.

The coalition in presenting its policies argued that six months was not long enough and said that a two‐year waiting period would be more appropriate. But nowhere did it suggest in any way that it intended to widen the nature or range of benefits for which an exclusion period would be provided, nor did it suggest in any way that there would be new categories of citizens who would be subjected to it. In fact, the whole presentation was on the basis that existing rights of Australians would be understood and respected. The now Prime Minister was able to approve Senator Short's press release on 19 February 1996 where he said that the coalition's proposal to extend the six months to two years was simply an extended application of the principle established by Labor in 1993. Of course, we still have the Prime Minister
saying the same thing. We still have the Prime Minister in the House saying deceitfully that what his government is doing is no more than an extended application of what Labor introduced in 1993. In blunt terms, that assertion is a lie.

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member will withdraw.

—In blunt terms, it is a misleading statement and it conflicts with the standards of integrity which the Prime Minister himself asserted were appropriate for the conduct of the parliamentary process. The measures that will come into force as a result of the government's introduction of new legislation were intended to make savings of some $616 million. That is a substantial saving but it was always implausible. It was implausible when it was first uttered and it remains implausible now.

speech.para: In the explanatory memorandum that was circulated with the bill introduced by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, the minister claimed savings of $29 million in the first year, $132.4 million in the second year and $171.1 million in the third year. That left a shortfall of something like $285 million, notwithstanding that in these measures they had, deceitfully and improperly, added every possible new benefit that one could imagine. It meant that these new measures now apply not only to those people who had entered Australia as migrants as we would traditionally understand it, but also to those who entered as spouses of Australians who are permanent residents in this country.

Let us just look at that last point—spouses. Australians, for example, might travel overseas and might meet and marry somebody overseas. Perhaps I would take a job, as I once did, as an academic at the University of Papua New Guinea and would marry. Many Australians do spend some time outside this country, and increasingly so, given the fact that we are exporting services and one of the things that we are specialising in is being able to provide professional services in the South‐East Asian economies. Many Australians will be travelling overseas to provide those services.

While we were there, if we had met and married some person who was not an Australian citizen and we had children and then returned to this country, previously we would have expected to bring that person here as of right. We would have expected that person to be accepted and integrated into the Australian community as of right and to be treated as another Australian permanent resident and citizen.

This is no longer the case. Your new partner, no matter how longstanding the relationship, is treated as one of these persons who is a migrant relying on a two‐year waiting period. And as for your kids, they do not get the benefits that everybody else gets as an Australian. If they are born overseas, they get minimum family payment only. They do not get any access to things that were once known as the Family Allowance Supplement.

So here I am returning from overseas with my new wife, and because I did not meet and marry somebody who was a resident of a state in Australia, I suddenly have to find myself responsible for all those welfare payments if my new spouse becomes ill. We have to survive as a family even though I am a low income worker without access to the Family Allowance Supplement for my children.

All these measures were not anticipated by the coalition in the words of comfort they gave to the ethnic and Australian communities, and those permanent residents and citizens of Australia who are entitled to know if this was up anyone's sleeve. And the Prime Minister still sits in the House deceitfully saying that this is just an extension of Labor's principles.

break.para: As the Deputy Speaker quite properly identified to me earlier, there are proper processes of this place to deal with deceit of that kind, and there are processes to call upon persons who have the responsibility to answer for that deceit. So this is not the forum in which to use the strong language which I did earlier. But, nonetheless, strong language is appropriate because this is not a circumstance which we should allow to pass lightly. The costings will not be achieved.

Today I have seen a document of amended costings circulated again, where additional financial savings are intended to be made. No explanation has been provided for this. We had briefings the other day in relation to these measures from the department, and there was no anticipation of additional costings. This is an embarrassing nightmare for the government. They are millions of dollars shy of the costings that they anticipated when they produced their savings documents, the Costello documents. At the time the opposition said that those costings were manifestly absurd. We claimed that they must fall substantially short of what was being proposed for the opposition at that time. We were right. The proof of the pudding is in the figures that are now being produced by the minister herself in the supplementary documents.

So, firstly, we have got cuts to the humanitarian and refugee program which are intended to make $64 million of savings, notwithstanding an express undertaking before the election that they would not be touched. Secondly, we have the extension of the six‐month waiting period to two years. Bringing together a host of benefits into that compass makes it a cruel system which lacks compassion. But it is also a program which was not announced to the community before the election. It was deceitfully concealed. Yet even with all those changes, the costings fall far short. So we have an example of a failure of the government to make good the claim to savings that it had anticipated.

Now we are discussing the supply bill, and supply, of course, goes towards the funding that is necessary to carry on the business of government. One of the key issues at the last election was whether the costings of the coalition's promises and the costings of its savings measures were competent and professional. If you have ever seen any proof that they were incompetent and unprofessional, and built on a block of deceit, then you have had it in these measures. In aggregation, they still do not make the costings that they claimed in the first place. This is a humiliation for the minister. It has forced the minister in the Senate to deceive the parliament and it has forced the Prime Minister to make statements which reflect on his good integrity.

My final comment in relation to the area for which I now have responsibility as a shadow minister turns on the way in which the department is being administered. There are two issues. The first is the abolition of the Office of Multicultural Affairs. The lack of weight that the Prime Minister gave to this area was apparent in the fact that the position of minister for immigration is not a cabinet position. It is also apparent in the abolition of the Office of Multicultural Affairs.

That office was intended to be a coordinating agency to bring together programs so that there was a central government focus to ensure that the concerns of new arrivals to Australia or long‐term residents from a non‐English speaking background had a range of services taken into account in the planning of government decisions. That office has now been scrapped from the Prime Minister's department and has been given as a side function to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, which had no particular focus on those issues in the past. Because of that, these had to be taken out of the line agency, which was really only
responsible for planning for the process of immigration and the management of the refugee and humanitarian programs. It has not had, in the past, a good record in the area of access and equity.

That department has now been given these functions, but no money. So we have this miraculous process of imagined loaves and fishes, where a department—which is already reeling under major cuts to its own funding to do the tasks which it was previously allocated—is expected to pick up new functions from the Prime Minister's office, perform a coordinating role across the whole of government, but with no resources to do it. No wonder they are bleeding. No wonder leaks emerge from this government, falling off the backs of trucks like leaves in Canberra in autumn. They do not have the same colour, they are not as pretty, but they are almost as numerous these days.

One of the documents that came to us was the restructuring document. It sets out the changes that will occur within the department to make good some of the shortfalls that have emerged because of the deliberate decisions of this government not only to cut back the funding of the department, but also to impose the changes emerging from having to absorb the Office of Multicultural Affairs from the Prime Minister's office into the department, but with no funding.

One of the consequences, which my good colleague the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) will well illustrate when he speaks on a later occasion, is that it means that regional offices of the department in key areas all around Australia will close. It was asserted, for example, at one stage that some of the difficulties will be ameliorated by enabling some visits to take place on a mobile basis. The department has already got rid of most of the vehicles that were there for that purpose. We have this contractionary hard‐hearted approach trying to squeeze out every last dollar at the expense of the weak and the vulnerable.

I am delighted that I had the opportunity to speak briefly tonight. As the member for Jagajaga anticipated the larger issues, I focused on those which are peculiar to my portfolio, but each illustrates the steely resolve of this government not to address the key issues that it claimed it would be addressing when in opposition and contesting the last election.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Morris, Allan, MP

talk.start.para: —I want to cover some territory tonight. I want us to go back in history. I remind the chamber that parliamentary behaviour has become a major issue in some people's minds in recent times. I well recall that very vivid phrase, coined by the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) last year, that truth is absolute. He said that whatever he did in political life would be based on the fundamental statement that truth was all, truth was absolute. There were no half‐truths. There were no misrecollections. Truth was all.

speech.para: That, of course, was prior to the elections—and during the elections the major thrust of the now government's campaign was endorsement of the then government's policies. The present government went to great pains to point out that Medicare would be kept intact and bulk billing would be maintained, that all the social justice programs would be sustained, and if there was a budget problem it would extend the deficit. In other words, keeping those promises and those programs was more important than any deficit issue.

That was heard over and over and over, because the questions were asked over and over. They were asked over and over for a couple of reasons, one of which being the exaggerated promises that were being made in terms of new programs. So not only was the now government promising to maintain the previous government's programs—with a few relatively
minor exceptions in the global scheme of things—but it was also offering a lot of new programs. It is in that area that life gets to be very interesting, particularly in terms of truth.

In terms of the budget savings which are being offered to offset these new programs, I am perhaps much less kind than the previous speaker because I think those figures were, in fact, deliberately wrong. I do not think that was any accident. The three areas that were put forward most prominently for cuts were the unemployed, migrants and public servants. They were the three soft touches—the three areas that you knew would get a cheer around Australia, the three areas people like to dislike. Post‐election, there has been a fourth one, which is Aboriginals.

When you consider what the campaign was doing, I think the comments made by Noel Pearson during the campaign were very poignant. In hindsight, anybody who did not read them then should read them now, because he was spot‐on: `All of us' meant `but not them'. And the `not them' were the public servants, the migrants, the unemployed and, as he saw it then, the blacks—the Aboriginals.

When it was suggested that the $600 million or more savings on the extension of the access to social security was exaggerated, there was a great hue and cry: of course they were not—the promises had been costed absolutely to the very dollar. The fact was that they were exaggerated because people were saying, `I always knew those people coming here as migrants were coming to get on our dole.' By exaggerating the figure, you increase the potency of the divisiveness of the message. And it was not accidental. That was no accident; that was quite conscious and quite deliberate.

In the same way, with the public servants, the 2,500, a natural attrition, was never intended—never, ever. The public knew that. Many of the public servants actually believed you and thought you were telling the truth because, more than most people, they probably would have read your speeches. They probably would have read the Prime Minister's statement that truth is absolute and thought, `Well, he is supposed to be an honest bloke.' Quite a lot of them were not around in 1977‐78 when there was the `fistful of dollars', or they had forgotten the 1983 budget projections. They actually believed you.
And, of course, the Aboriginals were not consulted at all. They were just off main focus—in the background somewhere. So you picked three soft touches and gave exaggerated—

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member for Newcastle might remember that I did not pick anybody. Perhaps you are referring to the government?

—The coalition picked three areas that were divisive and unpleasant. It exaggerated the costings to show how serious these issues were and it was saying, in effect, that the then government was derelict in wasting so much money in areas where savings of such a magnitude could be made. That was the cleverness of the deceit, because people want to believe that governments are negligent, particularly in those areas, such as the Public Service and so on. The fact that the Public Service had been reduced by 18 per cent in the previous seven or eight years did not matter. I heard one minister at question time in the Senate the other day actually criticising the previous government for reducing the Public Service from 180,000 to 150,000 in the previous eight years. And that was a criticism.

speech.para:
There is the fact that it had been done and you knew that. Many of you complained in previous times about your lack of services. Because of constraints, and because of the cuts to the Public Service, you knew there was not much fat left in the Public Service. The message was there. But now, post‐election, we are seeing a really fascinating exercise going on. Day by day, it is interesting to watch the shifting, the ducking, the weaving and the dodging
around.
Order in the House
captured it beautifully on Sunday night when the point was made that it is no longer broken promises, it is a change of policy.

I think the previous speaker, the member for Denison (Mr Kerr), referred to the extension of the restriction to access for support. This is not seen as social security support or the safety net support but things such as child care and family allowances. Previously, these things were not restricted at all. They have been brought into that election policy of the two‐year exclusion. The answers to the questions last week, which were re‐screened on Sunday night, picked up very well the shifting and the change in policy. The fact is it is deceit; it is a broken promise; it is dishonest.

And, of course, in amongst that there is this $8 billion fraud and, basically, it is a fraud. What the government is trying to perpetrate on the Australian people is a massive fraud. If the costings were not so accurate and you did not generate a $4 billion deficiency in your own promises—in terms of your campaign—why not release the Department of Finance costings? The previous shadow minister has pointed out that the savings in the area of exclusion from access to benefits for new migrants is short by hundreds of millions of dollars. There is at least a $4 billion gap in the government's commitment and its capacities. This attempt to project an $8 billion deficit is a fraud. It is a figment of the imagination of those who put together those costings before the election, and put forward the proposition that they were fully funded.

If anybody has any doubt about that, look at the legislation. Just go through it and look at what has come forward so far. Tonight we have been debating in the House the housing legislation. What does that do? For a government that is so strong on the rights of states and the idea of shifting responsibility to the states, to limit the funds available under the housing agreement to one year absolutely undermines the states. That is the worst thing you could possibly do. To give a billion dollars to the states on an annual basis only means that they cannot plan beyond a year. Therefore, they have to assume that the funds will be cut in the following year. How deceitful is that? How tricky and how sneaky is that? I think those comments from last year about being weak and sneaky that many of us thought would resonate very well are resonating now.

Let us look at immigration. People were told that the two‐year exclusion period was simply an extension of the previous government's six months. No, it is not. It is in fact a whole new issue. The member for Denison pointed out how many young Australians and older Australians will be affected by this. A constituent of mine, who is now an American citizen, has a father who has had a stroke. If he migrates back here, as he will probably have to, who is going to look after him? His father cannot because he is a pensioner. He will not get a carer's pension. How is he going to cope? He was forced to become an American citizen because of his wife and so that he could work in America. If he migrates back, as he is planning to, he has a huge problem. This is a government that really looks after the most vulnerable! The inclusion of the carer's pension in that exclusion period was not promised. It is an absolute deceit. It is sneaky, deceitful, deceptive and slippery.

We had another wonderful one just last week. Suddenly, after all the years of discussion and debate, out of nowhere there is a new Sydney airport site. Why didn't somebody think of it before? Why didn't it happen 10 years ago? You say, `The fact that there have been all these other meetings before the election, well, that is just coincidence. There were thousands of those going on.' But the thousands of other meetings aren't coming forward as proposals and aren't having an EIS funded.

break.para: Provisional tax: great policy, great stunt; lousy legislation, great con. Six per cent for one year only and then back not to 8 per cent but to 10 per cent on a year by year basis. Great con. Go back to small business and self‐funded retirees and tell them that that is what you really meant, because you never said that. You said that the uplift factor will reduce to 6 per cent, full stop—not for one year. They assumed you meant it for the life of the parliament. You asked them to vote for you for three years, not for one year. How many of you can go back to your community and tell them that that is what you meant? The fact is that you did not know it yourselves. A very small number knew, and some of you should be really squirming.

I took part in a parliamentary inquiry last year with the current Minister of Immigration (Mr Ruddock)—an inquiry into migrant access and equity. The report was finished prior to the election. We conducted hearings around Australia, in both capital cities and regional Australia. We ended up with a report which was unanimous and which he suggested the title for. It was called
A fair go for all
. It puts forward a lot of proposals to improve access and equity for people from non‐English speaking backgrounds.

What is his first action as a minister? To wipe out the access of people from regional Australia to his departmental services. That is a pretty good trick. That is a pretty consistent little trick, that one. He goes to the migrant community and says, `We care for you, we understand.' That report being bipartisan looks terrific, doesn't it? It is a really good backstop to credibility. So all of those members who represent regional Australia now, mainly from the government, need to explain to their constituents how the minister has acted. Go read the report. It is not a bad report. Go read it and just remember when you are reading it that your minister endorsed every single word. We spent days going through it, I can tell you, and he argued over every word of it. So he endorsed every single word and he is now the minister.

His first action is to cut the services at Townsville, Newcastle, Wollongong, Geelong, Chatswood and Sunshine—all gone. So much for access and equity. During our hearings the current minister was very concerned about OMA and the fact that it was resident in the department's offices. He was really concerned about that because, if it was going to be genuinely independent and have its staff in the same office, which the then government put forward as a cost saving measure, he was quite sceptical of that being genuine. So what does he do? He abolishes it. It is a nice twist. Those
Hansards
make interesting reading on the current minister's line of questioning and his perceptions of these matters.

Then we get to industrial relations: the big bang stuff, the radical agenda. No‐one will be worse off; no‐one will be worse off under your legislation. Day by day, hour by hour, we are all getting examples of who will be worse off. And what do you do? Deny them, twist, turn, change the words, make out that that was not said—all that obfuscating and all that twisting and sneaking and slithering around. You have only been there for three months. After three months, you have got dozens and dozens of issues running, all of which you are trying to deny.

No-one will be worse off, the government said. Just watch as the cases come forward, one by one, case by case. The ones who worry me are the apprentices because what you are really talking about is wiping out apprenticeships. Quite frankly, young people with ability are not going to work for the kind of money and the kind of commitment that you are putting forward because they know what the apprenticeship scheme pays and you are talking about effectively cutting their current wages by one-fifth. That is what you are talking about doing. And whilst
that is dishonest and deceitful and slippery and slimy and all of those things that fit you now so well, the fact is it will discourage young people who would be good tradesmen from becoming tradesmen because they will so distrust the system.

Quite a lot of them voted for you because they also thought truth was absolute and that you kept your promises and that `Honest John' could be trusted. Unfortunately, they are finding out otherwise and they are the ones I feel concern for.

It is going to be an interesting parliament as time unravels and as we see more and more of the detail of your agenda. I think most of the government members will be as interested as we are as to who the real authors are and what the real agenda is because most of the members of the government actually believed what was being put forward by the coalition during the campaign and they are probably finding out about the changes at the same time as we are.

I am absolutely convinced that the local members in the Hunter did not know about the closure of the immigration offices prior to it coming out publicly. I doubt if they know today that the DAS office has been authorised to be closed as of 30 June. I am sure they do not know about it. I am quite sure that the government members are as surprised as we are about all that is going on. They defended those costings as being accurate and reliable because their shadow Treasurer said they were. Their leader said they were and he was to be trusted because for him truth was absolute.
In a way you were probably more gullible than the people who voted for you and yet you should not have been because you should know better—

talk.start.para: —You should know better and address your remarks through the chair.
—I mean you collectively, Mr Deputy Speaker. You represent a whole lot of people tonight.

break.para: There is this unfolding panorama. Who wrote it, who owns it and what is behind it? We know what is behind it, that has become very clear. The first thing behind it is a transfer of things from the Commonwealth to the states—housing, health, aged services and home and community care. Go and tell all those people out there that from now on the state government is going to run their service. Why did you not tell them that before the election? Why did you not tell the aged community that you were going to move nursing homes and hostels to the states? Why did you not tell them that before the election? Was it because there are no cost savings available in that?

You cannot justify that with your $8 billion fraud. Why did you not tell the families of Australia about child care being transferred to the states? Why did you not tell them these things in advance because this just did not happen last week?
