These were all part of the plan—exaggerate the costings, create the deficit and then the need for drastic surgery. But the surgery is not saving money. Eventually it will cost more money rather than less.

Back in the 1970s the fistful of dollars description typecast the then Treasurer very well and very accurately. He promised before the election and then took away afterwards. The 1983 budget reinforced that, the then $9 billion, the 4.9 per cent GDP blow‐out reinforced it. People were persuaded this year that he was reborn. Well, the fact is he is not reborn, he is just reworked. He is weak and sneaky and slithering all over the place. It will be interesting to
watch the performance of the members of the government who were not in the know, who were not the authors, and how they handle it.
(Time expired)
That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

proctext.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

question.speaker: Nehl, Garry, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

question.para: (1) How many (a) nursing home beds, (b) hostel places and (c) Community Aged Care packages are provided in each federal electoral division.
(2) For the purposes of allocating the resources referred to in part (1), how many persons aged over 70 years reside in each federal electoral division.

answer.speaker: Moylan, Judi, MP

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The following table shows the number of:
(a) nursing home beds,
(b) hostel places and
(c) Community Aged Care packages provided in each federal electoral division and the number persons aged over 70 years who reside in each federal electoral division:

row.entry: Population data by Federal Electorate as at 1993.

entry.break: Hostel, CACP and Nursing Home data as at 1 April 1996

answer.to.qon.title: Native Title Act 1993: Cost to the Commonwealth

question.speaker: Cobb, Michael, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

question.para: (1) When did the Native Title Act 1993 commence.
(2) Has native title been granted in respect of any site in mainland Australia.
(3) How many persons, and at what cost, have been appointed to administer the Native Title Act in each year since the Act commenced.
(4) What are the details of the total cost of administering the Act in each year since it commenced.
(5) What would have been the outcome if the sum referred to in part (4) had been spent on purchasing land for Aboriginal persons.

answer.speaker: Howard, John, MP

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The substantive provisions of the Native Title Act 1993 (NTA) commenced on 1 January 1994.
(2) No native title has yet been recognised on the mainland.
(3) The number of staff and the exact cost is difficult to ascertain as staff numbers and functions fluctuated in different agencies during the years reported.

This table provides the number of employees of Government Departments and Agencies engaged entirely or predominantly in work relating to the administration of the NTA, and the approximate cost of employing them.

(4) The following table reflects the costs of administration each financial year (in $ millions) since the NTA commenced. As for the answer to (3) above it should be noted that the exact costs of staff are difficult to ascertain as staff numbers and functions fluctuated in different agencies during the years reported. Also the table does not include several Commonwealth agencies and departments which have staff who may occasionally be working on issues related to the NTA.

row.entry: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission **
‐ Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission
Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title
Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet

answer.para:
*
This is the estimate for the full financial year.

**
This figure includes the funding provided for Native Title Representative Bodies.
(5) There would be more Aboriginal owned land. The NTA would also not have been administered.
Without the NTA processes for establishing whether native title exists, lengthy common law actions would proliferate, overburdening both federal and state judicial systems with native title claims.

It is not possible to predict the impact of a slew of common law claims on the cost of administering the courts, but it is reasonable to assume that these would be greater than the costs of administering the claims process under the NTA, which aims to reduce costs by emphasising mediation.
